Dermot smiled back and said, "You deserve to enjoy yourself. And as I mentioned, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't worry about it." "No, that's fine," she replied.

**Title Race**

Human nature can be quite amusing. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of jealousy and tension at work. A survey by a top recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title over a pay raise. If our desire for impressive titles is so strong that it outweighs even the basic desire for more money, we are in a difficult situation. In today's world, no one wants to be seen as inferior. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways of saying the same thing.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light could change a scene and how a single photo could capture the essence of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture, as long as I had film in my camera. I once got lucky with a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well, which became famous worldwide. After that, I decided to work freelance, but things didn't go as planned. The mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped, even though my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which was fine by me.

The Vienna assignment came by chance. I had taken photos for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had captured different seasons in London and was ready to move on. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna project, and they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the other photographers. I was happy to go because things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna sounded perfect.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife during a busy summer, but this time was different. As soon as I arrived, I felt inspired by the snowy city. On the first day, I didn't take any photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. I wanted this to be my Vienna, not Schussner's. I waited for the right moment to take my photos.

The next morning, I was out at dawn. Fresh snow had covered Stephansplatz, making it look untouched and empty. I struggled to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was so tall, and the base was massive. I realized I might have to settle for a partial view, but it could still be magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even for the pioneers in the 19th century. Watching a photo develop in a dark room is mysterious, and that sense of wonder never goes away. So, when something unexpected happened at Stephansplatz that morning, I wasn't entirely surprised.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has become a place of wonder, not because of a big-budget show, but thanks to a unique exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that involves movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that creating art that moves or explores movement has been an important, though often overlooked, part of 20th-century art. Curator Guy Brett, who has studied kinetic art for many years, has put together a collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films. These are displayed without much explanation, allowing visitors to make their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art is popular with many people, even those who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some people might be drawn to Hockney's personality and humor, which make him a favorite in the media. Critics sometimes say Hockney is overrated, but this might be because being popular is not always seen as a good thing. Hockney himself knows his limits and doesn't claim to be a great artist. He believes that only time will tell how his work is judged.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some great and some not so much. What bothers me are shows that try to push a certain idea or trend among artists. Sometimes this works, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to do something different. I worked with seven artists to create an exhibition in an empty warehouse called 'Window-shopping.' The artworks were connected only by the fact that they were art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a specific theme, but they complemented each other through their differences. I didn't make any big statements about contemporary art, but that's okay because art is a personal activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who love paintings sometimes avoid analyzing them because they think it might ruin their experience. Some say that art historians focus too much on theory and ignore the joy of simply looking at art. This is like saying that knowing how a dish is made takes away from its taste. Understanding more about art can actually enhance our enjoyment. Pleasure is complex, and how we experience it can be influenced by the society we live in. While it's important to appreciate the sensory experience of art, the idea that thinking about art takes away from its enjoyment is outdated. Art can be both a sensory and intellectual experience.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble. It didn't feel like a regular stone, but it was attractive. This is how gold might have become part of their lives. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became a popular material. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they eagerly searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This is how metalworking became one of the skills that improved their lives.

**St Ives**

We walked silently, carrying our bags down the winding, cobbled street leading to the town center. We struggled against the strong wind and tried to avoid the cold waves crashing over the promenade. The streets were empty, and the shutters on every waterfront cottage were tightly closed against the storm. We had watched the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small single-track train. As the dark grey skies closed in, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car didn't seem like such a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with promises of beautiful coastal walks and cozy evenings by open fires.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived through peaceful times and hardships are long dead. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed families, clans, villages, and cities are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We can't replay history. However, computer modelling offers a solution. It allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities—digital versions of humans with some real-world needs and abilities. We can set rules for behavior and create social groups. Then, we can change conditions, like reducing rainfall or increasing population, and observe how this digital society reacts.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth observed a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby. This stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean the dominant male would lose his position. To prevent this, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, he gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn about leopards. This scared the stranger back into the trees. The trick worked until the dominant male made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while casually walking in the open, revealing his deception.

**What Cats Catch**

In the English village of Felmersham, residents collected prey caught by their cats. Over a year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor estimated that, based on these numbers, cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this calculation is misleading because most cats live in towns and catch fewer prey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes, as many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations high. The survey showed that cats are significant predators but not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are very important to marsh people and are well cared for. Every morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping area slowly and with groans, heading to the reed beds. They stand at the edge, complaining about the day's work, until the leader moves into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and rest there for a while. Eventually, they start moving so slowly that it's hard to notice. They swim with just their noses above water, looking exhausted. They spend the day among the reeds, eating leisurely.

**PICASSO, Pablo - The Soles, 1940**

In early 1940, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and some soles. The fish and crab look alive despite their situation. The painting is complex, with overlapping transparent shapes and soft colors, creating a calm underwater scene. However, there is tension, as the fish and crab seem ready to fight. The sharp forms and even a chain around one fish add a sense of danger, giving the painting a symbolic meaning.

Photography has been a tool for capturing human life and activities for the past 150 years. In this short time, it has grown to capture moments in time and space, allowing us to see both fleeting moments and vast or tiny details. Photography has shown us images from faraway places on Earth and in space, as well as the complexities and crises of modern life. It has become a powerful way to express the human experience.

However, using images to record events is not new. The earliest examples date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. We don't know exactly why early humans created cave paintings—whether to record hunting events, as magic to increase animals for hunting, as religious symbols, or simply to decorate their living spaces. But images have always been a part of human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and their importance in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has given visual images a special status. When photography was invented in the mid-19th century, it promised to provide a truthful visual record automatically. The camera, like the human eye, was seen as a tool that could capture a fixed image, very close to what we actually see. This was a major achievement, as artists had long worked to develop the skills to create such images.

Photography was thought to be a "universal language" that everyone could understand. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even isolated people could understand a photograph of the sky. But as global communication increased in the late 20th century, we began to question whether photography could truly cross cultural differences. Is photography as influenced by cultural norms as language is? Our familiarity with photographs might make us overlook the medium's ability to convey reality.

Photography is often seen as providing clear evidence, making it seem transparent and blurring the line between reality and its photographic representation. It's common for someone to show a photo and say, "this is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and attitudes towards it have changed significantly. Photography has moved from being a simple record-keeper to becoming part of "mythic time," where images have become historical documents revealing much about the people and society that created them.

The camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography can inspire social and political change. Just as the development of perspective was crucial to the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance, photography has played a key role in shaping the media culture of our time. It also brings the harsh realities of the world into our everyday lives, like on a coffee table.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching someone how to write poetry is tricky. It's like walking through a minefield: you need to be spontaneous, but one wrong move can ruin everything. Claiming to know everything about poetry is risky, so instead, I suggest that beginners should read a lot, write often, and let their imagination and spirit run free, as long as it doesn't lead to chaos. Some people need a stable life to write a poem, while others can write even when they're unhappy. Some follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration. All methods are valid, as long as they aren't just copying someone else's rules. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, you can't have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to explain something. A good way to do this is through a quick memory in the main character's mind, which can help move the story forward. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different sides of a situation quickly and keeps the reader interested. Writing too much can ruin a short story, but that doesn't mean it should be as short as a summary. A short story needs to have conflict and action, just like a novel, but every word must be important because of the limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. Many chess players don't know much, but they know enough to play. They make moves without knowing what will happen next. Over time, they learn that chess is more about long-term strategy than short-term tactics. They start to see the whole game, not just individual moves. In chess, as in screenwriting, the more you practice, the more you understand its complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin once said that humans naturally speak, as we see in young children, but they don't naturally write. Language is found in all societies, and while languages change, they don't get better. English today is not more complex than ancient languages. All healthy children learn to speak without lessons. When children are together without a common language, they create one. Writing, however, has been invented only a few times in history, in complex societies, and it developed slowly. Until recently, most children didn't learn to read or write, and even today, many struggle. Children are naturally good at speaking, but writing is a skill that must be taught carefully. We need to understand how writing works and how children's minds work to teach them effectively.

I have never started writing a novel with more uncertainty. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to name it. I don't have much of a story to tell, and it doesn't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader with an open ending. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between those times. I could make up details to fill the gaps and make the story more complete, but I don't want to do that. I just want to share what I know. To protect the privacy of people still alive, I've given them made-up names and taken care to ensure no one can recognize them. The man I'm writing about isn't famous. He might never be. When he dies, he might leave no more impact on the world than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. But maybe his chosen way of life and his unique character will influence others, and people might realize that he was a remarkable person. Then, it will be clear who I'm writing about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limitations, will be a helpful source for his future biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I've included are exact quotes. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for things that matter to me. I've written these conversations in my own words, but I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I haven't invented anything, but I've taken the same liberty as historians to create speeches for people in my story that I didn't hear myself. I've done this to make the scenes more lively and realistic. I want my book to be read, and I think it's fair to make it engaging. Intelligent readers will notice where I've used this technique and can choose to ignore it if they wish. Another reason I'm nervous about this book is that the people I'm writing about are from a different culture. It's hard to truly know people, and I think you can only really understand your own countrymen. People are shaped by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they played, and the poets they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't fully understand them unless you've lived them. You can only know them if you are them. Because you can't fully know people from another country just by observing them, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I've never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I've done so in short stories, it's because you can describe characters more briefly there. You give the reader broad hints and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I don't claim that my characters see themselves as I describe them; they are seen through my eyes, just like the main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the literary world often seems confusing to those experiencing it. It's only later that we can see clear patterns and recognize important figures. Today, poetry is especially complex with many different styles, debates, and ideas about the poet's role in society. Generally, there is a divide between 'literary' poets, who write for reading on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer performing their work to an audience. However, this division isn't strict.

Public poetry readings have become more common over the last twenty years. These events happen in various places, like small town halls, schools, colleges, and arts festivals. The impact of these readings on poets is mixed. For 'pop' poets, who write specifically for live audiences, these performances are beneficial. Their work is often simple and easy to understand in one hearing, but may seem lacking when read on the page.

On the other hand, poets who focus on crafting their work with depth and complexity might not be fully appreciated in a live setting. They might feel pressured to choose their most accessible poems, which might not represent their best work. Listening to poetry readings is not a replacement for reading poetry, but it can be a helpful addition. Hearing poets read their work can show where to place emphasis, but it's best if the audience has the text or knows the poems beforehand.

The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to make poetry enjoyable and accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It's a mistake to think that someone's spoken account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the person being interviewed influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to cover. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status compared to the interviewee and how the historian has learned to interpret history, which might affect the interviewee's responses. Historians must acknowledge their role in shaping new evidence. However, challenges remain even after the interview. The interviewee's memories might be influenced by other sources, like the media, or altered by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions and attitudes can make the testimony seem convincing, but they might not accurately reflect the past.

**Animal Science**

Animal science can be studied in two main ways: focusing on physiology or on the whole animal. Physiologists study how the body functions, such as how nerves and muscles work together to create complex behaviors. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of the entire animal and what influences it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are distinguished. Psychologists usually work in labs, studying how certain animals, like rats and pigeons, learn. Ethologists study natural, instinctive behaviors, often in wild settings. Although these fields are merging, physiologists often claim their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding nerve cell functions doesn't eliminate the need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own structure and must be studied at its own level. Describing a bird's nest-building by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

New social science students face the challenge of learning both the content and the methods of their subject. They need to understand the knowledge and research findings in textbooks and the methods used to gather and organize this knowledge. These two aspects are closely linked. Since we all experience social life daily, social sciences might seem like common sense. However, textbooks show that each social science goes beyond common sense. Each focuses on a specific part of social life, uses particular study methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts form the 'logical basis' of the subject, allowing social scientists to go beyond everyday understanding and distinguishing one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek terms for some of these ideas, likely from an earlier Greek source. Utility and function are not part of his definition, though he later discusses the best designs for different purposes. Initially, the focus is on aesthetics, viewing architecture as an art. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple constructions in Greece and Italy that didn't meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These early structures, though basic, contributed essential elements to later sophisticated architectural designs. Despite their elaborate appearance, classical temples are essentially simple, single-roomed huts.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. Despite this, Chen found it amusing when he discovered what Lily had been doing. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange; Chen should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, leaving early and returning by midday to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily practiced driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily, however, felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit it. Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, and Chen even applauded. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a small street with many empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings, so she preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed or fined. This cautiousness might have reassured Mui. On the way, Lily noticed Mui's tense face in the mirror and thought it best not to add to her worries.

Lily locked all the van doors carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked, "no one will want that heap of tin." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He held Man Kee on the railing, feeling the warmth and responsiveness of his son. In that moment, Chen decided to raise Man Kee his way, ensuring he got a good education and eventually owned many restaurants.

The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future. He saw a ship on the horizon and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it clearly: a small, old tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the eyepiece. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked. "It's a special ship for us. It may look small and old, but we know better. It will take us back home when we're done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you've never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily put her arm around Chen. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was gone. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, leaving Lily with a view of seagulls following the ship's wake.

Text: 'THE WELL I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't consider how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle but then let go, and I fell into the well. I hit my head and saw strange lights, like the stars and planets you see in cartoons when a character gets hit. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to see if I was okay. I was about to shout back when you called again, sounding panicked, which stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I could hear voices from the castle. Mother and Father came out with you and Arthur. Mother was upset, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to where I was hiding. I was scared someone would see them. Father was shining a flashlight into the well. I couldn't believe no one noticed the drops. Mother was screaming, and I felt guilty. I realized my prank had gone too far and would lead to serious trouble. I regretted not thinking it through. I decided to act like I had just escaped. I came out of hiding, pretending to be weak and exhausted. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled through it. I thought they believed me until Father asked me to repeat the story. I added that the tunnel collapsed after I got out, hoping to stop them from checking. But Father didn't believe me. He looked at me with disappointment, and I realized he saw through my lie. Arthur also looked at me with pity, worried about my character. Their reactions made me feel ashamed and regretful.'

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, now a widow, is leaving her family home as her children have grown up. The moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it, and indeed, everything unique about the house was being packed away. Fred, the removal man, with his large fingers, carefully handled the fragile items, while his team was less gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house overlooking a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there lingered like dust in the air. 

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, then five, had asked, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Now, Robert was there helping with the move, making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also helping, insisting that only she could handle the Steinway piano properly.

Fred, the removal man, noted that Susan didn't seem like she was going to cry. Susan asked if people often cried during moves, and Fred explained that they do, but they feel better once everything is at the new place. Susan could understand this feeling. She would have warned the movers about the piano, but Robert insisted it was their job to notice any issues.

The piano was in the best room of the house and would be moved last. Sitting on the stairs, Susan remembered when they first moved in. The piano had been brought in first and got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for hours, and Francesca, then a child, cried that they couldn't live without a piano. Her husband Peter had solved the problem by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to bring the piano in. It was an expensive process, and they couldn't afford to tune the piano for months. Peter had said, "That's there forever," but forever is a long time.

Now, the children were busy, and Susan found it hard to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and the imperfect banister rails, feeling she should have warned the movers. But it was too late. Fred reassured her that only the piano was left to move. Susan felt emotional, realizing how moving things made them seem important. 

As the piano was carefully moved down the stairs and out the door, Susan, Robert, and Francesca laughed with relief. They walked down the path together for the last time, arm in arm, with tears of laughter in their eyes.

Title: Online Literary Criticism for Everyone

The idea of open access to the Internet was meant to allow anyone to publish or share content. In reality, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that truly became accessible to everyone was literary criticism. With Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could write book reviews. Amazon's approach allowed anyone to express their opinion on a book and rate it up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because it provided free reviews for Amazon and gave potential buyers insights from other readers, not just publishers or professional critics. Other online bookstores offered similar features, but Amazon, being the largest, attracted the most reviews and also faced the most issues.

This open review system led to some problems. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily, and it was impossible to check them all. Amazon had a team to ensure reviews followed guidelines, such as not allowing single-word reviews, personal attacks, or spoilers. However, reviewers were anonymous, and inappropriate reviews were only removed if noticed by Amazon's team. This allowed for some mischief, like authors writing fake positive reviews for their own books. For example, Lev Grossman wrote fake positive reviews for his book after receiving negative ones. His fake reviews were removed once he admitted to the deception.

Authors could also comment on their books through a special link, but Amazon didn't verify if the comments were truly from the authors, except for well-known writers. For instance, a fake comment pretending to be from John Updike was removed. Most issues arose from reader reviews. When James McElroy's book "We've Got Spirit" was published, it received positive reviews from the press but negative ones from people mentioned in the book. These critical reviews disappeared after a few days.

Despite these challenges, Amazon saw the high number of reviews as beneficial for business. Reviews were meant to be a forum for discussing books, not a chat room, so Amazon closely monitored reviews of bestselling books. Silly reviews were more likely to be found on less popular books. For example, a humorous review of "The Story about Ping," a children's book, compared its plot to Internet architecture.

Overall, most reviews on Amazon were serious and provided a good indication of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books required inventing feelings about them. This makes the democratization of book reviews a positive development.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, we often talk as if every artist must rebel against the art of their time. We praise art for being unique, revolutionary, or even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to contemporary art, we hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, questioning if it can still be called art. The media often voices these doubts for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in today's art. We want artists to be different from the rest of us, with special talents and energy that break conventions. In the past, people commissioned art for specific purposes, making it part of everyday life. Today, we let artists work independently and get annoyed if they try to be more relatable.

**Picture This**

Let me describe a situation and ask an important question about it. An artist selects a piece of text from an art book. The text questions the diversity of pictures, asking, "What are they all about?" and concludes, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter is instructed to write the text on the canvas in simple black letters, without any flashy or charming style. The question is: Is the finished product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th, there is an unspoken rule in the art world that once an artist finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect consistency, and trying something new can disappoint the public. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and the art-buying public often seeks comfort in continuity. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, successfully break this mold. Eric Rimmington is another artist challenging expectations. His new show moves away from the still lifes he is known for to paintings of the London Underground. Rimmington has always been fascinated by railways. His earlier drawings of Kings Cross Station led him to explore the underground world. These sketches inspired "Underground Encounters," an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings capturing the unique charm of this hidden world.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to put it that way. Apart from an old peasant woman who comes daily to clean, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel suspended in memories. I spoke about the uselessness of art but didn't mention its comforts. The solace in my work as a painter or writer is that in silence, reality can be reimagined and shown in a meaningful way. Our everyday actions are like a rough covering hiding the true beauty beneath. For artists, art offers a joyful compromise with life's challenges, not to escape destiny like ordinary people, but to fulfill it through imagination. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

Text: 'Family Business'

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my final exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling about what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you'll get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said, trying to act confident. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also hear," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you can talk well, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see in TV dramas."

"Be that as it may," he said, pulling himself together, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the family business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."

The problem was that, like many children in family trades, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw different career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was usually right about these things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't a burden. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, fancy schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew all kinds of people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."

"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and especially the depression and sulks my father would fall into if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on safer tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused and used these last days wisely, he might be right. I felt confident and concentrated.

This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's understanding (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his time of need. That wasn't all. As he explained the task, I saw more clearly than ever his single-mindedness - the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, his energy, and self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being extremely careful with money, which wasn't ideal. At first, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at an advertising agency with a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. Lois was the one who pushed for the move, arguing that their flat wasn't suitable for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. These needs could have been met in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She felt their old address wasn't suitable for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. 

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him resentful. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where his grandmother made sure his grandfather had peace after a long day in court. But times had changed. Lois made it clear before they married that her career was as important as his. Their lifestyle depended on both their salaries.

Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who was very upset when she confronted Simon. She accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors four years ago and that Cartwright had given shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial felt weak even to himself. He felt guilty and remembered feeling similar shame as a child facing punishment. He wished he had been prepared and could have said that Cartwright only mentioned the bribes after the trial and that he didn't believe him. But he lied directly, and Venetia knew it. Simon wondered why she was so angry and if she had the right to ruin his career. He wasn't sure what she could do, but even a rumor could destroy him.

I chose to live here because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn't care if their rented houses were falling apart or if their gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops start to recognize you, even if you're not living your "real life." The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, trying to ignore the summer outside, but tonight I'm watching the swifts fly between the trees and roofs. I've cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from cutting back rosemary and lemon balm. It's a small London garden where plants have to grow tall or spread out to survive.

My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished manuscripts, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to be interested in them. I have her latest one now. "How's the work going, Jaz?" I ask. "In no other job do you have to explain yourself a thousand times a day," she replies. Then she offers to bring something to drink from her fridge. I don't really want her in the garden, which now looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. "You're on holiday now," she says, lounging in shorts and a vest on the chair. "I should've gone into teaching. Writers don't get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can't, teach." And some can't do either. "So, what are your plans for the holidays?" she asks.

I feel anxious about the school year ending. Empty days, hot pavements, and loneliness in the park. "Actually, I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?" I ask, my heart racing. "Of course," Jaz says, knowing she will be around. "Where will you stay? A fancy B&B?" "No, I'll stay with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight." It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. "Going back to your roots. So, what do you think of my manuscript?" Jaz asks about her work, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I've only half-read. I like the title and tell her so. Red vans can seem cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and rejection letters to hers. I decide to be honest. "Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good," I suggest. "Teachers!" Jaz responds like a rebellious student. "I keep a journal," I say, "where I write something good about each day." My words sound old-fashioned. "Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann," Jaz says.

Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen reassures me. Then I suddenly remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking at us and saying, "I've had my moments." We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to the past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and their lives. Beyond personal stories, there is a need to learn about our broader past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel secure about the future by understanding the past. Just like inheriting genes, we inherit culture passed down through generations. Even if there are parts of our national heritage we don't like, it is still part of us and provides a sense of belonging. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. Traditionally, we connected with the past through stories from our ancestors. However, Western industrial society disrupted communities, leading to the loss of many oral traditions. Now, places and buildings help us understand our past. It is crucial to preserve these links to honor our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became important. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose this setting. I picked the Fens because they seemed plain and empty, a perfect backdrop for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are neither flat nor empty. They are as English as any other part of England but also strangely unique. It's surprising that in the middle of England, the Fens feel foreign to many English people, even though other distinct areas have become part of the nation's cultural heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, open yet mysterious. My research for the novel wasn't extensive; I haven't visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer imagining worlds rather than seeking documentary proof. Imagining the Fens has its logic because, as Edward Storey's book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility means more. Displays should be lively and interesting, using theatrical or architectural techniques to engage visitors and evoke emotions. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artefacts and specimens, not replicas. They offer encounters with authentic items that existed and had meaning in history. This is their strength, setting them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and offer exciting displays, catalogues, and outreach programs will find that virtual history can actually support them by increasing interest in the real items they offer.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things isn't new, but changes in our towns happen so quickly now that everyone feels their impact. This can turn some people into strong preservationists and make others think more about the nature and future of towns. It's reasonable to say that people who have lived through events like world wars are more inclined to preserve things than those before them. Stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change isn't bad if we learn to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, like changes in population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**

If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to sell products related to intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some complex theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that don't match everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a big change in scientific thinking, which marked the start of modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe in a new, more logical way by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

When we were children, Lydia and I didn't trust books that won prizes because we thought they would be 'worthy', which to us meant 'boring'. Our mother didn't like our attitude and often criticized us, but our father would happily give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these 'improving' books. He would also sneak in some better-quality books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, marking them with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we ignored most of these books as 'boys' books', he did manage to introduce us to some good short stories and, once, a famous collection of poems.

**Language**

In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'the origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mysterious origin has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller suggested that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad, and humans in dangerous lands full of scary animals might have made desperate noises. Some words in languages today might still echo these sounds, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death". Because of such odd theories, many people avoided discussing the origin of language, thinking it was a topic for eccentric people. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa around 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and played a key role in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, despite philosopher John Locke's idea of language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode explores the art of writing reviews from a writer's perspective. Most reviews are created and shared under conditions that make them relevant for only a short time. There are deadlines and strict limits on their length. Once published, they last only as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear in—maybe a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often defines their literary value. Many people, including the writers themselves, often think that reviewing is a job done out of necessity, like needing extra money, or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a skilled and complex task. Writing a concise and fair review in 600 to 800 words for a newspaper is different from writing a detailed 6,000 to 8,000-word piece for an international journal. A 1,500-word article in a weekly magazine combines challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, from casual weekend readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer needs to know a lot about various topics and write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This means reviewers often write other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who sees criticism as staying close to the shore, still enjoys writing reviews between his major novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with modest titles. While some might think less famous writers should accept the temporary nature of their work, it's understandable if they want some recognition, especially if they believe their best writing is in their reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike some other cultures, there's no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it's common for the same people to do both. The days when academics criticized professors for writing reviews are mostly over, and complaints from non-professors about professors taking their opportunities are less common, partly because there's more reviewing work available now. I believe this is good for readers, who can trust that the reviewer knows what they're talking about, and for professors, as it helps keep them grounded. It also reminds them to communicate clearly with non-academics. While they might use complex language with each other, they need to be clear when addressing intelligent non-professors. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and entered the dark, still hallway. Even after three years, he sometimes felt a brief unease about owning the place when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, wondering what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or plumbing issues, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or the answering machine would have messages, which he appreciated. He was glad the windows weren't broken and nothing was stolen, though he wondered what it would look like if it happened. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his evenings alone at home. Once he left the office and started his bus ride home, he felt more like himself and didn't need to be alone anymore, though he often forgot this when planning his social life. At his desk, he longed for solitude and time with his belongings, but once home, he felt empty and waited for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him think that his unsatisfying job had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music at night, but now questioned why he did these things. His sense of direction and purpose had faded; thoughts and feelings would come and go without finding a place. He remembered a time when he felt more in control and might have escaped his situation if he had realized his own value. After university, he tried to plan for a better future but found he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs his friends talked about, following their paths without imagining a job that would make him happy. He went to one interview and didn't think to evaluate the job, an editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was just relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he now faced daily. Neil offered him the job on the spot, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed through crowds, ice-cream vans, food stalls, and loud music to get a good spot. The racecourse was a simple area marked off for the event. It wasn't like professional racecourses, but people stood on either side of the track to watch the goats race. Keeping the goats in order was a challenge since they are known to eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I worried about the night ahead. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we used a torch to see the cliffs, but the batteries were dying. We replaced them, but the new ones didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley thought she saw a light, and we got hopeful. It was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued on.

**How to be Presentation Perfect - We Answer Your Questions**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I often have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? 

You're not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must first convince yourself. Show your belief through passion and enthusiasm in your presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas in advance and ask colleagues to think of tough questions the audience might ask. Start by creating a positive atmosphere. Begin with something everyone can relate to and gradually lead to your main point.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush making mayonnaise by adding oil too quickly, it will curdle. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will tighten. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done quickly, while others take longer. We can get faster at solving puzzles or doing math in our heads, but some things can't be rushed. If we try, they might fail, like the mayonnaise, or get more complicated, like the fishing line. Sometimes, saying "Think fast; we need the results" is as silly as trying to sleep in half the time. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds, suitable for different tasks. "He who hesitates is lost," says one proverb. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. The mind has three processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an instant reaction. When my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my brain and body reacted immediately, and only afterward did my conscious mind catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer doesn't have time to think about their next move. This fast physical intelligence is like our "wits." Then there's thought itself, which involves figuring things out, weighing pros and cons, and solving problems. A mechanic fixing an engine, a scientist interpreting results, or a student working on an assignment all use this kind of intelligence, which we call "intellect." People good at this are called "bright" or "clever." Below this is a slower mental process, less clear and more playful or dreamy. In this mode, we are ruminating or meditating. Sitting by the sea, lost in the sound of the waves, or just before sleep, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind to wander is not a luxury to cut back on when life gets busy. Slow thinking is essential. We need the slow mind as much as the fast one. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some mysteries require a relaxed mental attitude. Recent studies show that patient, less deliberate thinking is good for understanding complex or unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well when the problem is clear. When deciding where to go on holiday, the options might be obvious. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to ask, or when the issue is too subtle for conscious thought, we need the slow mind. If the problem is managing a difficult team at work or deciding to change careers, it might be better to ponder than to search frantically for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets have long known the limits of conscious thinking and have embraced these slower ways of knowing. Philosophers have written about the parts of the mind beyond conscious thought. Only recently have scientists begun to study these slower ways of knowing. Cognitive science is showing that the unconscious mind can do many important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns too subtle for normal consciousness, understand complex situations, and solve difficult issues better than the conscious mind.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been warmly welcomed here. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very remote area. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers - forming a close community where everyone helps out. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not for casual conversation. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my confidence. I found myself slightly dreading mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure which table to choose, worried about the silence when I spoke, feeling anxious like I did in my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think this occasional sadness isn't about missing company or communication; it's because I've lost the social advantage my speaking skills usually give me.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author like any other, and he didn't pay much attention to me. However, he never forgot a face, and when we met again, he would shake hands with me politely but didn't try to get to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he often pretended not to see me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to show more interest in me. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me out. After my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care much about the story or the acting in his films. He focused on the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical details. For Hitchcock, it wasn't the message or a great performance that moved the audience. He believed that people are affected by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is designed well for emotional impact, audiences from Japan and India should react at the same moment. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear and logical. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who enjoyed hearing an audience scream. He didn't deal with speculation or abstract ideas, and he didn't explore his screen characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues, and telescopes were basic. There were also few books on how to do practical astronomy. Today, you can buy almost any telescope or equipment you need. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we make almanacs and charts, and they help us analyze observations and publish results. This could be considered the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can last for hours and turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Society today has too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. In the new economy, people always want the latest product or service, and technology makes changes happen faster. New products come out quickly, making it hard to keep up. This can make people feel tired and disconnected from life. More choices mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. Because of this, people are looking for 'simplexity'—simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it has become very important to us. Nothing can interfere with this ritual. The guests at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned, maybe a bit odd, and some might say snobbish. I dislike the rude behavior of shop assistants today, which is seen as being equal. I also don't like overly friendly waiters who seem like they might slap you on the back. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them in the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Such respect for dignity and privacy is rare in commercial places these days.

**Othello**

The move of an outstanding production of Shakespeare's play "Othello" from Stratford to London gives me a chance to correct a harsh review I wrote when it first opened last spring. At that time, I criticized Ray Fearon for being too young for the main role and unfairly judged his acting. I still believe that changing the age difference between Othello and Desdemona alters the tragedy, but I take back my criticism of Mr. Fearon's excellent performance. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Memorable scenes include Cassio's competitive games with other young officers that become dangerously intense, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I dare anyone not to be moved to tears during the scene where Emilia helps Desdemona prepare for bed. The pace and tension throughout the play are fantastic. Don't miss this production.

**Lake Vostok**

In the center of Antarctica, nothing moves. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the vast white plateau inside, life cannot survive. Except, that is, in a huge hidden body of freshwater called Lake Vostok, which lies under nearly 4 kilometers of ice, directly beneath the coldest place on earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange organisms live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For two years, researchers worldwide have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets, and if they succeed, the next few years will be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that a group of scientists is getting very excited about what motivates them to be scientists; the phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the timeless quest for knowledge, the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we want to know all of this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. Surely, it's more important to know whether what we scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. I would have thought that the key issue here is not why we pursue science, but to recognize that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**

Our connection with food is very basic and fulfilling. Many people who love cooking buy cookbooks like this one. Often, we think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complex dishes. But that's not true. You can make a delicious soup just by putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and a few herbs into water. This is much more satisfying than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with too much sugar and preservatives, you can make a delicious dessert in five minutes that both adults and children will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by bringing your own creation, no matter how simple, to the table. Sharing food is full of meaning and meets our deep human needs, which is why all our celebrations, like birthdays and anniversaries, happen around tables. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party! And not many people would want to discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to tidy up his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from desk drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing them. Plus, there was extra paperwork from owning an apartment building. Books and journals were piled near the new bookshelves. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on the hour. She was very precise about time and neatness. How would she react to the mess? She might think his office had been vandalized. He could pretend to be shocked when he walked in behind her. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her hopefully as she unlocked his apartment door. Her look said she had no intention of cleaning his office. She believed he was from somewhere far away, not from her familiar world in Brooklyn.

**KAREN**

Karen wanted to be different from her mother, which led her to create her own story of strength. In her personal story, there were important moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she was blind, but the doctor assured her that the bone had protected her eye. She only needed a few stitches, which healed as a reminder of her past suffering. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles and small mercies, she felt she was saved for a purpose.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty was walking back to her duties across the wet grass of the village green. She felt both excited and sad about what she had just seen. It's thrilling to be the first to know something important, especially in a small community, and Miss Fogerty's life was usually quiet. But she was very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years, and she appreciated his care for her yearly throat infections, which were her only health issues. She valued how he always made time for his patients and truly wanted to hear about their worries. This quality made him very loved in the village. He was always ready to give his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received great loyalty and affection.

Joanna's Lessons

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. Despite her hectic schedule, she has started writing books for young children learning the piano. Her performances are so captivating that even someone who is completely tone-deaf would be moved. Watching her play is like seeing a pianist push human limits. However, at a recent concert for children, one boy was not impressed until she played "Match of the Day," a popular TV theme. For Joanna, this was amusing. She realized that in his eyes, she wasn't a real pianist until she played that tune. She easily played it and likely remembered the experience for future children's concerts.

Joanna is unique among top pianists because she is interested in how young children learn the piano. She has published her own beginner piano book for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World," even with her busy schedule. This summer, she is involved in many festivals and projects, including running her own recording label, Sound Circus. She often collaborates with other artists. So why take on writing a book? Joanna believes the first lessons are crucial. She thinks the music profession focuses too much on creating child prodigies, while most people have a more ordinary interest in music, which she finds more interesting.

Joanna's experience comes from teaching beginners between the ages of 18 and 25, before she became a concert pianist. Her childhood was filled with other children learning piano from her mother, which influenced her approach to music. She believes everyone should have the chance to learn piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French. Some children progress quickly, but she is more interested in those who take their time and enjoy it, even if they eventually stop. She worries that some parents push their children to achieve in music, rather than letting them enjoy it. Children often quit because they can't meet their parents' expectations.

Joanna's books are not the only ones designed to make learning piano fun, but she has a unique approach. She includes a storyline in her books and CDs to make learning interesting. From the first lesson, there are accompaniments in different styles for teachers or parents to play along with the child. If parents can't play, the CDs provide the music. Joanna insists that learning should be fun. She encourages improvisation and exploring the keyboard.

As children progress, they need to learn to read music instead of just playing by ear. Joanna understands this challenge because she relied on her ear as a child. However, she believes practice is the most important factor. She admits she didn't practice seriously until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she had to practice to handle difficult contemporary pieces. Now, she enjoys practicing for eight hours a day, which she considers the core of her musical life, even more important than performing.

Joanna sympathizes with those who find practice difficult and believes it's not discussed enough. Her advice is to plan what you want to achieve before practicing, treat yourself by playing the whole piece even with mistakes, and mix hard pieces with easy ones.

Writing by Hand and on Screen

Dr. Johnson once said that writing without effort is often not enjoyable to read. This suggests that good writing is challenging. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice there were few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was physically hard, which made me think more carefully. The slow process of writing by hand disciplined my mind. Since it was hard to change or erase, I wrote with care. On the other hand, using a computer can lead to carelessness. Many writers find that the time spent fixing early drafts on a computer is similar to the time spent writing by hand. Also, emails, unlike handwritten letters, can be emotionally heavy. Some say emails have brought back the art of love letters, with millions being sent instead of just casual talk. That's a good thing. At least these emails are written in some form of English and grammar. But words on a screen can feel dull. Writers often don't realize the power of written words and may exaggerate their meaning. Words typed quickly lack the care and personality of handwriting.

The CD

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not impressive, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Aren't they amazing?" Mr. Warriston said as he came back into the room. I agreed and carefully handed the disc to him. "It's incredible they can fit seventy minutes of music on them," he said, turning on the hi-fi device. He pressed a button, and a small drawer opened. He placed the disc inside, pressed the button again, and the tray slid back in. "Some people say they sound sterile, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston said, standing up straight. "No, you only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked puzzled, then thoughtful. "You know," he said, "I have no idea. I don't see why you couldn't make both sides playable and double the capacity..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers, or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He nodded at my wooden chair. "Anyway, let's get you sitting in the best spot for the stereo effect, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.

Books versus Electronic Text

When comparing books and electronic text, author Malcolm Bradbury was right when he said that if matches were invented after lighters, we'd be amazed by the improvement. Many people, excited by new technology, claim that electronic text is as revolutionary as the invention of printing and that this change is almost complete. They ignore that changes in how we think take generations. This kind of talk falls into the trap of thinking our generation is at the center of history. For example, a book from 1979 predicted that the 1980s would see books slowly disappear. So far, that prediction was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is often unpleasant, so most people don't do it. Also, the way information is organized on computers encourages people to read only parts of texts. Some technology enthusiasts argue that this leads to new forms of storytelling and creativity. But there's nothing new about "non-linearity."
