Many books, like religious texts, dictionaries, and poetry collections, are not read from start to finish. What's new is that computers don't encourage reading a whole text in one go.

The Office

Charles walked into the office and saw a perfectly organized space. The carpet was free of the paper mess that had covered it since it was laid down, and the desk was dark wood, just as he remembered from the Sotheby's auction five weeks ago. Neat file-holders were being placed in their drawers. Twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves on one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You need to switch to computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. Oh, this is amazing." He admired the room and its antique furniture. He wasn't thinking about a computer or any other device, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had this conversation many times. She couldn't understand why he resisted technology when he was so skilled with computers and had even published an important paper on computer-related talents. She had inspired that paper. With a keyboard, she could transform any software into something new and exciting.

Text: "You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for months. Her excuse for forgetting was that he wasn't usually supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that staying away would lead to chaos. He thought about how he had gone from being a valued advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to a stressed worker with no parking space at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a manila folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Below it, it said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot didn't want to see another synopsis. He wanted to see a "First Draft." Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was one of several old friends Lancelot had made the mistake of commissioning books from. Ian was proof that people with unpredictable temperaments become even less reliable when working with friends. Lancelot skipped the introduction, which he had read many times, and looked at the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and set it aside. It was clear Ian's manuscript would never come. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and felt like it had lost its conviction. Lancelot remembered stories of a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death, with payments made chapter by chapter. But in that case, the payments were from a hypothetical advance that was never given. Ian's advance was huge, going against the business principle that authors should deliver a manuscript before being paid. Lancelot, who studied modern languages at Oxford, remembered when Ian was the most promising talent in a Cambridge full of promise. Ian's peers had taken over British theatre quickly, but Ian's energy seemed like laziness compared to them. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous French writers as if he had overheard them. Yet, Ian's creative talent remained hidden. While others succeeded, Ian withdrew further. At the peak of his influence, he was difficult to work with. Appointed to edit an arts magazine, he was like a general stuck on the beach with too many opportunities. The magazine used up its budget without publishing once. His contract with a fashion magazine led to stories about his large salary, which increased to try to make him produce more, and then anything at all. At editorial meetings, Ian was witty but harsh, criticizing others' ideas. Ten years later, he was unreliable even for his own funeral. Lancelot was close to admitting that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the start.

Text: 'The breakfast change in England

Health experts agree that having a good breakfast is very important. However, historically, breakfast is a relatively new concept in England. In medieval times, breakfast was rarely mentioned in literature. There are some references to travelers eating at dawn before long journeys and to sick people having breakfast for health reasons. But most people, except for kings and nobles, did not eat breakfast. In the sixteenth century, breakfast slowly became common for everyone. Some believe this was because food became more available. However, they often overlook other important social changes. For instance, new work patterns might explain why breakfast became more important. People started working fixed hours, often very early in the morning. So, having breakfast became necessary and was no longer just for the wealthy.

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to include based on their technical skills, artistic taste, personal opinions, and experiences, along with social and cultural norms. In this book, we will explore how these factors influence the style, content, and expression of a photograph, and how viewers perceive and react to these images. For instance, a newspaper reader might have an implicit understanding of the photos they see. However, instead of accepting the photo as it is, we might ask if it truly shows the scene as it was. Or, does it reflect the photographer's perspective? Is the exact moment captured important, or should the photo be seen as a symbol representing a situation in the world?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport has always been more than just a game. The most successful athletes have complete self-confidence. You need to focus entirely if you want to succeed in sports. There's only one way to be the best, and you have to prioritize it above everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's a matter of survival. Sport has taught me personal discipline and determination, but it also shows the value of teamwork. My sport allows and encourages individual excellence, yet it is a team game, and you must balance these two aspects. It's much like life—you can succeed individually, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot—not just money. It has opened doors for me and broadened my perspective, allowing me to see things worldwide that others might not. But you also have to sacrifice a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences are so vivid that they become clear memories. For me, one such moment happened one night in California years ago. I lay awake, listening to the beautiful singing of a mockingbird hidden in one of the tall trees in the neighborhood. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing singing kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I found myself in an unexpected artistic experience. To follow the bird's patterns, I had to use my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an incredible, spontaneous musical performance. I reacted with groans and cheers as each surprising musical variation came through the open window, until I finally fell asleep.

Text: Human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. But what does that say about us? Paul Evans reports. There's a bumping sound from the greenhouse as a small brown bird hits the glass. It's a wren, a bird often seen as a sign or omen. Is it trying to send a message from the edge of my imagination? Or is it just a bird trapped in a greenhouse? Both could be true, depending on your perspective. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, images of wrens are still found in British homes, even if the old beliefs have faded. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because folklore about birds is deeply rooted in our history, from a time when people relied on nature for survival. As cultures change, so do the meanings we attach to animals. For example, in the early 1500s, red kites were common in London and seen as helpful scavengers. But later, they were considered pests and nearly disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain. Our connection to birds goes back to early human history. The first birdwatchers observed birds to detect predators, weather changes, and food sources, and also saw them as links to the spiritual world. When we ask why birds matter to us, we're also asking about our own identity. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and envy. Some might say these feelings are outdated, but like the appendix or wisdom teeth, they are still part of us. Birds have become indicators of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is not only a loss of unique birds but also a cultural loss. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing symbolize love and magic. Their decline is felt deeply by those familiar with literature and folklore. However, the loss of birds not featured in stories often goes unnoticed. Folklore is important because it connects us to birds in a way that scientific terms cannot. It evokes feelings and attitudes buried under modern life. Whether watching wildlife films or birds in our gardens, the excitement we feel is hard to explain scientifically. Birds engage us in ways we struggle to understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and a distant past, holding its song as it flies into the future, leaving us with a mystery to ponder.

Maps are used to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in terms of time, like "a day's journey by river," which told more about how easy it was to travel through an area than the actual distance. Direction was less important for travelers who mainly wanted to know where to go and how far it was. Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, sometimes more so than maps. Even today, some maps, like those of railway systems, might not show true directions accurately. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of these signs depended on the map's purpose and where it was made, so understanding early maps requires knowing the conventions used at the time.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and adding more details to maps. Cartography has used other sciences to help with this. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it more accurately. Astronomers found out that the earth is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.

Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were no longer the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery, which required showing the land's surface features accurately. This led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also had specific needs for maps. Today's cartographers have developed ways to map various distributions, like geological layers and land use. The recognition of maps' value in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.

However, the development of cartography has not been a smooth, continuous process. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid development. Sometimes old ideas persisted alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what needed to be done but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since it was easier to copy old maps, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers were sometimes slow to adopt new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken as perfect evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and educational.

TIM RICE

I was invited into a young man's living room, which felt like a calm and cultured space compared to the messy rooms around it where his less ambitious family members spent their time. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a flight. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had encountered, and surprisingly, a teenager who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't a matter of life or death, though I can say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was open to trying it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' LP collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for instant praise for his music and a real, released seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) that an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier, which ended their failing career. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in the music charts than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to make a big impact on musical theatre, probably very soon. And even if we didn't succeed in challenging the top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, the certainty I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would, of course, keep looking at the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and would write a few more simple songs that wouldn't show the limitations of my voice, but it was still likely that I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would surely have outgrown pop music, as my father confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and to write lyrics that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. Andrew was a fascinating person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't really inspire me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, borrowing too much from Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in the brilliance of his score was infectious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title as well, most of which had probably been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Language**

Humans have an amazing ability: we can influence each other's thoughts with great accuracy through language. Language is so essential to human life that it's hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct.' This means that people know how to speak naturally, much like how spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a genius spider or need special training; it's just something they do naturally.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather, mainly created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can shape the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet conditions all year allow tropical jungles to grow, which are rich in different species. On the other hand, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. Daily weather patterns, which together form the climate, are caused by large air masses moving and mixing, as the atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement is because the air surrounds a spinning Earth, and since air is light, it doesn't move as fast as the Earth. However, the sun is a more important cause of air movement.

**Coffee**

As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and, more importantly, make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I went through several days of intense coffee-making training, learning more than I ever wanted to about cleaning and maintaining the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key steps to making a perfect cup of rich, frothy cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making a good cup of coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might be demoted to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to get the hang of it."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often fail to create good programs about visual arts like painting and sculpture? These art forms should be perfect for TV because cameras can show the whole artwork and then zoom in on details. However, there are few TV series that successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of viewing art. A good example of this issue is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which is about American art. Hughes is a reliable critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I expected the series to focus on great artworks, but instead, it was more about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market is less regulated than others. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is a normal part of the industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who thought the market would keep the prices of scarce metals stable have found the opposite. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its offshore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your accommodation doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis available. You can also rent a boat if you prefer to travel independently. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, naturally protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. It's not just the sea that has treasures. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Text: 'Build it yourself at the UK's first bamboo bike workshop

At the Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, you can join a course to build your own custom bamboo bike frame. It's a fun weekend activity in Hackney Wick, east London. On a Saturday morning, the Bamboo Bike Club is buzzing with activity. Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire leading the way. However, these bikes can be expensive, with ready-made frames costing around $2,995 or £1,868.

James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years developing their idea in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They realized they didn't just want to sell frames; they wanted to share the experience of making something unique and sustainable. This led to the creation of the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more of a community project than a business. James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, but they run monthly courses where participants can build their own bike frames.

The course teaches you how to select bamboo for strength and form strong joints. You start by assembling the front triangle of the bike with 40 mm diameter bamboo, then move on to the seat and chain assembly. Alloy tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. The process involves using jigs, power tools, and design blueprints, which can be challenging for those not used to DIY projects. However, James and Ian are there to help and ensure everything is done correctly.

Building the bike yourself is a big part of the appeal, and many participants are engineers. But even if you're not, Ian reassures that mistakes are okay and you can always try again. The bamboo is pre-checked for quality, and you can choose from different styles like plain, black, or mottled bamboo.

On Sunday, the focus is on building the lugs, or wraps, using hemp bindings and epoxy resin to create strong joints. A final polymer coating makes the bike waterproof. Once finished, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and other personal touches. These bikes are built to last and are as strong as metal ones. Ian has used his for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months without any issues.

Bamboo bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional frames, but they have a unique charm. They are ideal for a relaxed ride rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth, easy-going ride. The bikes are light and absorb vibrations well, making them comfortable to ride. James says the real joy comes when you take the bike on the road. The price for building your own bamboo bike is less than £500, making it an affordable and enjoyable project.'

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was just an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I took one look at the title and knew it would be a number one bestseller," she says, laughing. She was right. Dr. Gray, who is very understanding, is now a multimillionaire, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's small book on how to improve communication between men and women is a key part of the growing self-help industry. This industry claims to help Americans who want to improve their lives. It also benefits from these desires, creates many more, and supports the New York publishing world. Britain is learning that this genre can fill shelves with books that are as exaggerated as their covers. However, many self-help books are rejected for being too similar to others or too specialized, which is a relief. Editors are looking for the next big hit, and the writing style is not their main concern. What matters is how marketable the book is. "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" Ms. Reverend lists the key questions and admits, "If someone comes to me with a really catchy title, that's two-thirds of the battle won. You know you can reach people."

**Autobiographies**

There needs to be an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being told. This agreement is rarely fully kept. There are many reasons why a writer might not tell the whole truth. They might feel too ashamed to share certain actions or thoughts. They might leave out things they think are not important. There are also more complex reasons for not sticking to the truth. The writer might believe that inventing stories can better capture the truth about themselves than sticking strictly to the facts. Or they might decide from the start not to follow the truth at all. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, which helps them tell their story. Some readers might still believe it is true even after finishing the book, thinking they have read a true story when it is actually fiction. This can be done without any intention to deceive.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Experts on detective stories say this genre became popular because it reflects the conflicts of late 19th and early 20th-century society. A detective story is like a symbolic story. The crime represents human desires like lust or greed, and solving it, at least in traditional stories, shows how a person can fit back into society, calming their lawless desires so society can work smoothly again. In Hammett's unique version, society returns to its previous state, but it is shown to be corrupt and false. The detective and the criminal in Hammett's stories are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and are, in a strange way, comfortable with each other. The private detective is part of both the criminal world and the law. To criminals, he seems too honest, and to the law, he seems too shady. He is both a criminal and a competitor. The private detective's mission is sometimes affected by his feeling of being part of both worlds, and sometimes his desire to punish is stronger because he is worried about this ambiguity.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is considered today's greatest scientific essayist. To talk about his writing and get his advice, I met him at the Grand Hotel, where he was staying while promoting his new book. Neither of us felt very comfortable there. Gould said, "I couldn't write about a place like this: Trollope might, but he knew the culture. Understanding the culture is key to being a successful writer. Science, for example, is its own civilization. Only scientists can effectively present it. If you don't live in the community and don't understand its rules, you are at a disadvantage from the start." One of Gould's principles is to never underestimate the reader. "Make no concessions," he says. "You can simplify the language but must never dilute it. Above all, you cannot simplify the argument. Once readers feel they are being talked down to, your piece is finished."

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers during lunch, the air feels very cold. To cope with this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. At quieter times, it feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how air-conditioning is often overused in modern life. It has become a key part of work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other cooling methods. They could use natural light and ventilation and have thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and release it at night. These simple measures can be very effective and would greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It's not a coincidence that the start of a new millennium has brought renewed interest in sundials, which measure time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were essential for keeping clocks accurate. As clocks and watches improved, sundials became garden decorations—romantic but outdated in a modern technological age. Now, interest in them is growing again. David Harber, a sundial maker, believes their charm comes from their connection to the planets. He says there's a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago, where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on a teacup with precise brushstrokes. It was fascinating because each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged, suggesting they had either practiced for years or had a natural talent for precision. Remembering this, I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting course. Would beginners show natural artistic skill? In reality, the atmosphere was not intimidating. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher didn't want to paint petals on teacups as quickly and precisely as I remembered.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent mentioned that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. However, something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland instead of Venice.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe there was a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they landed, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in their brochure, but Keith thought it was just a stopover. It was almost midnight when they arrived at the hotel, and they were too tired to question it. The next morning, they realized they were supposed to stay there for the whole holiday, and they became worried.

The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained there was a mistake; they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping it would help.

A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne asked if she was in charge because they were in the wrong hotel. Keith explained they must have joined the wrong group. Mrs. Franks explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels, and it was easy to follow the wrong group.

Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, trying to remember everything that happened.

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, interrupted Keith's thoughts, saying they had a great night's sleep. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had insisted on this trip, even though they tried to convince him to come with them.

Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American executives are now looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports. In Britain, most people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal described Shackleton as 'an Antarctic explorer whose feats went largely unnoticed for most of the 20th century,' which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are showing great enthusiasm for him. Biographies and accounts of the Endurance voyage are being produced and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is organizing a major exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life. Some American managers have also started to see Shackleton as a role model. His admirers share stories of his achievements with admiration and draw lessons in leadership and communication from them. They even refer to each other as 'speaking Shackleton.' The determined and resourceful Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, has become a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, the managing partner of Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, chose Shackleton as a role model years ago. His firm specializes in 'communication aspects of mergers and acquisitions and corporate crises.' For example, dealing with situations like 'this firm's plant blew up' or 'half the workforce has to go.' While Shackleton once worked in public relations for a Glasgow steelworks, it might be hard to see the connection between surviving on albatross in freezing temperatures and handling a financial crisis. 'Even if a company manages its crises well, it can still cause harm by communicating poorly,' says MacGregor. 'Shackleton is a model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. He had his values in order and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most fascinating decisions was to turn back when only 97 miles from the South Pole. That decision showed his credibility for future expeditions: the lives of his men were most important.' This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole when, 97 miles short of their goal, with supplies running low and limited time to return to their ship, Shackleton made the brave decision to turn back. In a crisis, says MacGregor, people want to know someone is in charge. While managers today often avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take it on. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. When it sank, Shackleton told his men, 'we should all eventually reach safety if you continue to do your best and trust me.' From the accounts and diaries kept by his men, it's clear that Shackleton was always in charge. 'Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every possibility, kept his men informed, and sought their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was adaptable, willing to let go of losses and start anew. We've developed effective principles here that Shackleton exemplifies. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in desperate situations is to do nothing, especially in America, where the culture is against letting time solve problems,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and guess wrong on interest rates, you hold on, and eventually, you'll get your money back. To "fix it" and sell would mean a big loss. Similarly, don't be afraid to change plans if they're not working. If a new product fails, don't keep selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He forced his own gloves on Hurley, saying if he didn't wear them, he would throw them overboard. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving on the 1905 expedition: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' As Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, the human account of that expedition, says: 'The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton shows that there is little heroism today. Everything else fades away, and he stands as the true embodiment of the ideals we long for now.'

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that has a lifestyle similar to a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae by making holes in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak and long tongue, while the aye-aye uses its sharp teeth and a long, thin third finger. Although scientists knew about the aye-aye's feeding habits for over a hundred years, they recently discovered how it finds insects inside the wood.

Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her daughter Annabelle. He tested if they found insects by looking for visual signs, like holes on the wood surface. He gave them logs with drilled holes, some leading to mealworms and others to empty spaces. The aye-ayes went directly to the mealworms without needing visual clues.

Dr. Erickson also tested if the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects. They could still locate mealworms even when the smell was blocked and when the mealworms were dead and silent. This showed they weren't using sight, smell, or hearing.

Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes could sense empty spaces in the wood. They tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their large ears. He suggests they use echo-location, like bats, to detect hollow spaces. They might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that aye-ayes take the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting, but there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood. The aye-aye is unique because it combines traits of a woodpecker, an echo-locating bat, and even a squirrel. Its teeth grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat.

Text: 'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries give us small, incomplete glimpses, and family stories are often only half remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they are still just images. Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I've met people who have led interesting lives. They say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." The promise of privacy helps people be honest. "I had the confidence to be honest," says a 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune before making another. "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce, and the pain was still there." "I did it for my family, so they might learn something, but I haven't let my children read it yet. They were hurt by things in my life, and there are details I don't want them to know right now. If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone." He also saw patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has noticed this in others too. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "The things parents say and do affect their children for life. People often marry someone their parents would approve of, or they rebel and do the opposite." "Many disappointments come out. Even sixty years later, people regret or resent things that were never resolved with their parents. There is no age of reason. If people had issues in their youth, they still have them in middle age. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and if that fails, some seek permission to say 'I can't stand my mother.'" Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an interrogator and keeps her distance. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it anyway—they can remove it when they see the draft. But generally, people want to be honest, with all their flaws." "It's not vanity publishing. It's not people saying, 'I've had such an interesting life, the world needs to know.' Things are changing faster than ever, and we're losing touch with the past. This is a way to connect with our roots. We need a link to our ancestors because families don't sit together as they used to. People want a little immortality." Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, rearranging the timeline and interpreting. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the binding with its gold lettering: you can choose your own color and title. Fascinating to the private audience each book is for, the results are not about revealing secrets at any cost. Ms. Renier organizes her material logically and writes well, so the final content is as good as its subject. The book looks high-quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost, due to the time involved, deters many people. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I've worked with have all been well-off, readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They're the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**

The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few remaining collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over 600 pieces. It's important to know that none of the sculptures are original; they are all precise copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can view almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**

Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that hosts various photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books, magazines, and a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**

The Sedgwick Museum has an impressive collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also holds Britain's oldest complete geological collection, belonging to Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to trace major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with detailed labels explaining their nature and modern uses.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**

This collection includes over 400,000 oblique and vertical air photographs taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and conducts photographic work throughout Great Britain. The photographs are interesting as they provide a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape, showing both natural features and human impact from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with inquiries. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can be purchased, usually taking about a month to make.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**

The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world, and it's a unique tourist attraction. Visitors can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By creating resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while making brass rubbing accessible to everyone. Brass plates, an alternative to tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining brasses are in Britain, with a wide range available at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I've had 35 years of raising young children due to my unusual personal life, and I've loved every moment. This morning, I fed the baby, and to me, that's what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky with my children. We all enjoy opera, theatre, books, and music, which has created a strong bond between us. Now that they are mostly grown, I've become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical punishment. I've slapped my children in anger before, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I've always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, it creates a burden of guilt. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, around 25, and I found the responsibilities challenging. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which has been helpful for my work at the agency. I never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy building my business, so I missed some events like first concerts and sports days. I'm sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and join us at parties and advertising award ceremonies without feeling shy. I think it's an advantage that they see my job as glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public appearances if my kids can come with me. This way, they understand what I do when I'm not with them, and there's no feeling of me disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we're all realizing the importance of involving our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about fatherhood. I made great efforts to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other so the kids could come and go freely, but Kate and Bonnie found it confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently complained that we were too liberal. I think I should have introduced more structure and order. Instead, I took a very relaxed approach, which I regret now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never really leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house. We thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you're also just one more parent in a long line of parents. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her dispels it. A baby's smile is the best way to melt a grown man's heart.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's long play about a powerful warrior can feel endless, but Terry Hands' version is one of the most exciting shows this year. He has cut a lot from the original text, making it fast and full of action. Antony Sher is amazing as Tamburlaine, performing stunts like somersaulting from a balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. His intense performance captures the audience's full attention. Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two couples talk on a sunny lawn. The second act shifts location and becomes a deep, emotional look at the impact of illness. Wall was a promising talent lost too soon at age 44. Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)

C. **Amphibians**  
Irish playwright Billy Roche's new play is set in Wexford and explores the decline of the fishing industry. It features rich characters, strong emotions, and unexpected humor. The play can feel a bit unfocused but ends with a powerful climax. Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers trying to kill each other. The plot is familiar but cleverly executed. Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)

E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. Originally at the Swan in Stratford, it now plays well on the Barbican's main stage. Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce deliver excellent performances. Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic. Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a charming take on Beauty and the Beast set in London suburbia. With a lush score by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a delightful show. London producers should take note. Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is almost disappointing, but saved by great comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as Ford. Most of the cast seems uncomfortable. Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. This play about a seemingly respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son is excellent. Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He pulls her into a world of lies and crime, using her feelings for him and trying to separate her from her friends. Coppard creates believable characters in Emma's friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense, especially when she is trapped in the basement of an old house. The book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always protectors. It's a powerful and convincing read.

**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to uncover the truth. The reader, along with the characters, works hard to understand what happened. It's a clever and complex novel that rewards careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit well into her family or the male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story has a strong message that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story of rural prejudice through the eyes of a mature woman, Rose. She rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. Strange things in the cottage and a fierce cat reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting Rose and her children in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's ruthlessness. It's a gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam, from the poorer side of the family, is in awe of his sophisticated cousin Lisa. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It's interesting for both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with humor and confidence, setting the story in New Zealand. Robbie takes a job gardening for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, she finds him fascinating, but later repellent. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium, the story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It's unusual and compelling.

**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled personal relationships and difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a sensitive teacher. It's highly recommended, though it's a painful read, especially at the end.

Title: 'Science Defying Gravity'

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their theories in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular aircraft. The pilot informed the young passengers that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, based on the Boeing 707 passenger plane. However, appearances were misleading, and the 13 students from Europe and America were about to experience an extraordinary flight. Inside, the plane was transformed into a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except for a few at the back, where the nervous young scientists sat. They had spent 12 months competing with other students across the continent for a chance to be on this flight. The European Space Agency challenged them to propose creative experiments to conduct in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, which can be described as the most extraordinary roller-coaster ride ever created.

For the next two hours, the Boeing's flight would mimic a giant bird flying erratically, soaring upwards and then diving towards Earth. The goal was to achieve a brief moment of weightlessness at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued to rise due to its momentum before gravity pulled it back down. In the few silent seconds between climbing and falling, the aircraft and everything inside became weightless, and the 13 students would feel, in theory, closer to the moon than to Earth.

The aircraft took off smoothly, but any remaining illusions that we were on a regular passenger flight vanished when the pilot put the Boeing into a 45-degree climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood drained from our heads, and bodies were scattered across the cabin floor. Then the engines cut out, and the transition to weightlessness was almost immediate. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We drifted aimlessly; the idea of direction lost its meaning. Only gravity, by anchoring us, allows us to understand the concept of moving somewhere else.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its dive. The return of gravity was less immediate than its loss but still sudden enough to cause some students to land with a thud. With the first curve completed, some turned green at the thought of the 29 more to come. Thirty curves provided ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. The Dutch students quickly began studying the movements of Leonardo, their robotic cat, to understand how cats always land on their feet. At the right moment, they released their device, which floated belly-up, and one student managed to turn it belly-down using radio controls. However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on it during a less controlled return to gravity.

Next to the slightly dazed robotic cat, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how the quality of metal joins is affected by the absence of gravity, with future space station construction in mind. Another team from Utah State University explored the possibility of creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They spent the flight trying to produce these films in microgravity. They believe that once perfected, satellites could use solar sails to harness the sun's radiation, similar to how a yacht's sails use the wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unsettled, but the main feeling was exhilaration, not nausea. This was an experience that would stay with us for a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I was already aiming to become an astronaut, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had the idea of buying a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you take the time to plant it with trees, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice since my father grew up there. They found a plot about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very fertile, but it was good for planting trees.

I've always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing various farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees appealed to me, and I was eager to start. The rest of the family became enthusiastic as we progressed. We started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was a very rainy winter. It rained almost every day we were planting, and I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for another day of planting. Coming out of the Land Rover warm and dry, with rain pouring down, wearing a damp anorak from the day before, boots soaked, and hands struggling with wet laces. During this time, my mind would wander, and I would have many thoughts and reflections about life.

In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You carry a planting bag around your neck filled with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it's difficult, but it gets easier as it empties. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. You decide the spacing for the trees, line up three poles across a long distance, and those poles guide your lines. Once aligned, you plant down the line, turn around, and come back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically, finding a rhythm and using the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs, where you train your body to perform standard moves, making the process easy: taking a tree from the bag, digging a hole, planting it, stamping it in, and moving on.

Mentally, it was fascinating. My mind would wander, and I would have many thoughts about the natural world and our place in it. These ideas have since become central to my life. I've returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying because I planted them and feel connected to their success. I worry when I read about storms or droughts in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.

In 1984, I took a break from teaching and returned to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There's a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. My connection to that area is still very strong. It's the place where I feel most connected to the earth, a powerful bond.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

When one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box, my first thought was, "What now?" Six years ago, my husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm,' and since then, we've become known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the box—a mix between a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar to me. Curious, I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early life underground. If orphaned, they usually die of starvation and are never found. These three were brought in by building contractors who accidentally disturbed their sett while laying drain pipes. The mother was found dead with her babies still suckling her. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the mother's licking, which helped them relieve themselves. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. With each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute 'mum,' they seemed content. 

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, although he was still eating normally. It was a warning sign I didn't recognize. The next morning, I found him dead. A vet's post-mortem revealed Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, in such a small animal. Disheartened by my failure, I continued caring for the others. Then, six days later, a local farmer who heard about our cubs brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. The area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. Willow II joined us. At six weeks, he was about two weeks younger than the females, and I soon discovered why his mother left him. He was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around in his mouth and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn't drunk all day. By the end of April, the females were weaned onto creamed rice and then anything else. Willow was different. He was happy to give up the bottle but couldn't eat without walking through his food, tipping it over, or sitting in it. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly chewed, played with, and finally ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready to try other foods. 

At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, my foundlings had become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the cubs would get excited, fluff up their fur like snowballs, and chase each other's tails. As 'human badgers,' we were part of this game. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, never did and sometimes reacted colorfully to being caught. During these late-night walks in the dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely extending their territories to find food, as badgers are territorial and will kill intruders. We were warned they might climb into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep them out. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so great that we started an appeal to build a sett on the farm for them. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walking direction. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for viewing from a darkened enclosure. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they forgot the walks in favor of climbing through the tunnels and arranging bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the appeal, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers with a home of their own. 

Early one evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to find them curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. These days, my walks with them are less frequent, especially since they aren't fully awake until midnight. We see Primrose only occasionally, as she has joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still rush up to greet us before dashing off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

Text: 'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, his important work was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't accurately use their compasses to find longitude and navigate the seas. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip was stopped due to crew problems, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it outdated. Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the journey, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' Dr. Clark says. 'He was a respected scientist and explorer. He wasn't just an astronomer; he also did geophysics research. As Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and had other interests.' During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his book Principia Mathematica, the foundation of classical physics. Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. 'We usually measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field because you need to know true north for that,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find true north.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the Atlantic Ocean. Ground-based measurements are useful for comparison. Halley's Atlantic journey was very important. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian naval captain focused on declination. Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to succeed? He spent two years in Antarctica, works in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, and has sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews. Is he as dedicated as Halley? 'I'm willing to spend eight months on this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where survival is tough, how did such extravagant features evolve? Darwin believed that evolution happened through natural selection, where the strongest and most adaptable survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' He thought females chose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a practical reason. The impressive tails might signal some hidden quality that helps survival. Today, this debate continues because studying peafowl behavior is challenging. At Whipsnade, researchers like Marion Petrie are trying to find answers. They want to know if peahens really prefer males with the most eye-catching tails and if these males have other advantages.

Observations suggest that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails. However, it's unclear if these males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy birds might be healthier and free of parasites, but this hasn't been tested in Whipsnade peacocks yet. This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier.

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if females start preferring slightly better tails, this preference and the trait itself will grow stronger over generations. This could explain the peacock's tail and support Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on design changes from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly anchored in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. You might think I'm a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses the charm of old boat designs, but modern technology made it easier to build. However, while technology is important in boat design today, it often separates sailors from the real experiences of being at sea. These are the experiences they wanted to find by sailing. I'm not saying sailors should suffer through every hardship. I always make sure my boats have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. But why sail if every sail sets and furls itself automatically? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the sailor's life. And why should we move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? Sadly, this is done to create a cabin as big as a room at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, which I sailed around Britain for a TV race, the former owner said it had every comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned how right he was. Her sails were heavy, and she had no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I ever sailed. However, classic boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized I had to let go of my 15-year relationship with her. I couldn't find a suitable new boat, so I decided to build one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett use computer design, Irens first sketched the boat on a napkin and then used the computer. After creating a model, we refined the design. The final version was perfect. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails beautifully, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed purely as a sailing boat, not based on furniture. This traditional method proves that you don't need to follow trends to be satisfied. Built with wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to review some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was excited to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm immediately. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like body conditioning, yoga, and stretching. The instructors are very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The hour-long facial made me feel refreshed. The staff were friendly and professional, creating a lively and enthusiastic atmosphere. Henlow plans to renovate soon, adding a half-size Olympic pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or enjoy a peaceful walk in the garden. By the end of my stay, I felt energetic and happy. This is a perfect getaway for a stressed working woman. I can't wait to return! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

From the moment I entered this grand home, I felt calm and relaxed. The Hall has a beautiful library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can have privacy if you want. Upon arrival, everyone gets a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were called "patients," which felt strange since I was healthy. However, they found a shoulder issue during my check-up, and the fitness instructor helped me with it in group and individual sessions. Each person follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting but got a headache on the second day from hunger. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit with yogurt and broth for dinner. If you're not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is delicious. You get a massage or water therapy every other day, and extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge.
