Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be updated easily. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann ensures that rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food at the hotel must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He got to design a modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular restaurant without financial risks. With advanced technology and skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.'

Susan Shepherd is an artist famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially along the two long flower borders next to the path that goes from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left behind plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny initially doubted some of her ideas, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one, building the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the process of flowers decaying fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers, thinking they looked artificial. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden includes plants from distant countries, but they thrive as if they belong there. Susan has a relaxed approach to gardening, similar to an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She now has an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

In March, strong storms hit the Brackham area, knocking down many trees. In the town, two large lime trees were lost from the old market square, changing the town center's look, which upset some of the more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who leads the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, he was too sick to notice because he had a serious case of bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt a headache and chest tightness, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. But Pelham, believing the police needed him, ignored her and kept working. This only made him forgetful and irritable. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. She quickly got him his antibiotics and took him home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree in their garden had fallen, Pelham couldn't process it. That evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged, was relieved to hear it wasn't, and went back to sleep. It wasn't until Saturday, when he felt better, that he noticed the walnut tree's absence had changed the living room's look. The Pelhams' large house, which they bought for its private, leafy garden, now felt different. The walnut tree had provided nice light patterns that hid the worn furniture they brought from their old house. Without the tree, the room was very bright, showing the shabby furniture. The view was also worse, as the tall, unattractive house next door was now visible, with its purple bricks and many windows seeming to watch them. "Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said to Molly. But she, standing in the doorway, seemed more happy than upset. "I've been telling you since we moved here. We need a new sofa, no matter the cost," she replied.

Living in the Valley

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, and within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. On the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; trees swayed, but the branches stayed firm. Yet, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they didn't trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that threatened us the most. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was to come. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was gradually washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and nearing danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream was wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we'd ever seen it near our home, fiercely hitting its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only occasional overflows. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the large clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Mark Adams, a film critic, reflects on his last ten years working for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first serious job. Before that, he had done some reviews for novels, films, and radio. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, through radio and television work. Tom hired him, but he wasn't mainly a journalist, or he might have been more selective with his team. Initially, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover arts like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio, which didn't need specialized knowledge. They planned to have weekly lunches to choose what to review, with guests to keep things social. It felt like a dream to Mark, being part of a new newspaper in a crowded market. He even doubted it was real, thinking maybe a millionaire was just pretending to employ him. The first time he saw someone reading his review on the London Underground, he felt awkward.

Tom's idea for a team of critics didn't work out. It was a good plan, but they ended up working over the phone. The public preferred critics to focus on one area, so Mark chose film. Thanks to Tom's initial push, Mark now writes a detailed weekly piece on one film, which suits him well. He wouldn't have liked the usual film critic's job of reviewing every film, as it would quickly bore him. He enjoys having the space to expand his arguments or create something interesting even in a dull week.

Mark wonders about his role as a critic. He thinks people choose films based on stars, publicity, or directors, and rarely change their minds because of a review. For example, someone who dislikes westerns probably won't watch one just because of a review, and a fan of romantic films won't skip one because of a bad review. So, if reviews aren't really guides for consumers, what are they? Mark believes his job is to present an argument, not to be 'right' about a movie. He doesn't think there should be a set number of 'great' or 'bad' films each year. He sees himself as someone who shares his perspective, not as a judge.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because she thinks it's fun. A teenager with a passion for endurance sports is looking for a training partner. Ideally, this person should be female and interested in becoming an Olympic champion. They should love distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoy training in cold rivers), and distance cycling (enjoy 100km rides). They must be able to do all three activities without resting.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It attracts large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, and running 10km without stopping. But what drives these athletes to push their bodies so hard? And why would a talented 17-year-old with excellent grades choose this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that athletes often use. She says, "You swim 1500m, then jump on your bike while still wet, which makes you cold. After cycling 40km, you have to run 10km, which feels long when you're tired. But it's great fun and worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, although she was the only junior competing. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Despite having the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place well. She got lost during the cycling part and ended up riding 20km too far, crying through the run. But she didn't give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop to end the pain, but I'm afraid if I stop once, I'll be tempted to do it again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, but unlike most people who stop when they can't go further, she kept going."

Melanie was the top junior at this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but slower at cycling. That's why I'm working hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents, who are paying £1,300 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy her a £2,000 bike. This would help her compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, her intense training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I keep in touch with the other girls on the team by phone and letters." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our race times."

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon 'sprint', which involves swimming 750m, cycling 20km, and running 5km. She wants to try even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's surprising, isn't it?

Text: 'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It's a world full of passion and excitement. But remember, only collect things you truly love. People have been collecting since ancient times. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty and wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their shapes and colors. I've been a collector all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote, windy part of England. My parents took me to a local museum filled with historical collections, which fascinated me. Many adults share this interest in collecting. Some people collect because it gives them a sense of control in their lives. For me, it's simply enjoyable. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be wealthy to collect. I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a bulb, only for it to be stolen later. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. Seeing the remains of my collection was heartbreaking. I'm fascinated by how collections change hands. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value in the market. As small items become popular, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw mine away along with the toys.)'

**My Line of Work: Four People Talk About Their Jobs**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic first and then talk to experts to decide on the main themes and goals. I plan what objects and pictures to show. It's important that visitors understand the exhibition, so I plan interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure the exhibition is safe. Before it opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to advertise it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for learning the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are here, figuring out the best routes using the correct streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. When students are close to the test, I challenge them by asking them to find different routes, even if the first one they choose is correct. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but mostly I am by the coast. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the sea. I take them out on a boat to help them understand marine life better. This often changes their perspective compared to just looking at a computer screen. I love my job because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means we always need more money, so I can't do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is quite varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and manage the stock of about 300 books we publish. We maintain high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is there is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have expanded it, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school because Dekko Deacon sounds nice. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it's quite a coincidence. "How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." These are the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that, while her husband handles redecoration and repairs. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt the others thinking our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur led us to the rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others taking the cliff path to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, this routine had developed. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are characteristic of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but an enjoyable way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7a.m. to walk the mile or so to the chalet, which sleeps up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing that of the guests. 'They get the works - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit and croissants.' When the last of the guests has had breakfast, by about 9.30 a.m., Sarah clears up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go on the slopes herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4.30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course affair, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning madly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shop on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4.30 p.m.' Sometimes they are disorientated and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says. '

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory, and sometimes he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how Marie's father made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet.' 'Well, you should visit one if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry, with remains found from six thousand years ago in Turkey, I think. The first clothes were just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it's an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for days. That's common: people in the glove trade love it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have.' 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. She was innocent but eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. The intelligent curiosity that filled the house when Marie came home from school, full of what she'd learned. How she remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we'll do. We'll take you through the whole process. Come on. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it really a dream job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that seem perfect to find out if they really are. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often has to travel at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small issue - she hates flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt so cramped with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. Her tasks include organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for this job. She met a pop group's manager by chance, which led to a job offer. She also took secretarial classes in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. He preferred being a caddy because he loves golf. But there are downsides. Caddies get a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings. They usually earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes on travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at age 31. 'It's not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge of the weather, and try to understand the course.' His accounting skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards. TV commentators, golf magazines, and golfers all want these results. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern edits the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is trying food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking skills led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an advertising agency, and the column was a good extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% pay cut,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a career.' He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's author in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I used to be a farmer and knew about the problem of foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's book.' Where does he get his ideas? 'It's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out my morning notes - all with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy that part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. One afternoon, bored with nothing to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof into the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. They hesitated, looking pale, but one by one, they jumped and laughed with relief. In the hot sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Eventually, one of them said, "Let's go back up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they climbed back up and jumped off again, determined, until only Michael was left on the roof. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them but stayed on the edge, nervous and unsure why it seemed scarier this time. They thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists, trying to count to ten and jump. When that didn't work, he tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. The others got tired of waiting and started laughing at him. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they began to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, staring at the ground, feeling unhappy. He was alone for nearly an hour as the sun set, a big orange ball in the sky. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, and fell heavily onto the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a bit of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled sternness, but Michael, feeling gloomy and miserable, barely heard her. He was still thinking about his friends' grinning faces and their laughter.

Text: 'Careers Advice Are you unhappy with your current job but unsure how to make a change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change careers are turning to careers advisers for guidance. You'll need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help identify your strengths and suggest possible career paths, along with any retraining you might need. I decided to try Career Analysts, a large career advice organization. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions quickly. It was important to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics involved tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on this chat and the test results, the adviser wrote a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn I didn't do well in scientific, technical, and practical tests. It's probably a good thing I didn't become a nurse. However, it was reassuring to hear that I made the right choice in pursuing journalism. Changing your career doesn't always mean a big shift. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't realize I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities,' she says. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move into a field better suited to me than insurance. I'm now a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to several friends, who are all happy with the service.' Some people feel they wouldn't have made such progress without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make life-changing decisions. 'After working for a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I didn't know what I wanted, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.' However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I was at a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice.'

Text: 'Fun at the Dentist's? When you enter W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit during their check-ups. Jerome explains, 'Half of the people only visit the dentist when they're in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. They're scared.' To change this, he has created a space where people feel comfortable. That's why I decided not to wear a white coat. I think people link it with pain. My belief is that dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and enjoyable setting.' This is surprising for many of us who think of dental visits as painful or at least formal and clinical. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences.' One of his new relaxation methods is virtual-reality headsets. 'We were the first in Britain to use them, and they're very popular. During the first check-up, the patient sits on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then the headset shows a camera view, giving the patient a tour of their mouth.' Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says, 'When people come in, I want them to feel with all their senses that it's not like a typical dentist's visit. Smell is crucial. The usual dental smell can make people anxious if they're afraid of dentists.' I found the gentle smell in the office very pleasant. Although known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. Relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of treatment is the most important. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a bit unusual at first, but if people are relaxed, it's not painful. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to study dental techniques. 'I learned that making it easier for the patient makes it easier for yourself,' he says. He sees his patient-focused approach as the beginning of a gradual shift towards less formality in British dentistry. Just then, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.'

Title: The Rise of Chocolate

Chocolate, originally from South America, is now a huge global business. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, which is about 8% of all chocolate sales. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. Although large-scale chocolate production started in the 19th century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago.

The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish preferred it with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in European capitals where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the 19th century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, combined cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French charm. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, launched as Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising linking it to the healthy qualities of English milk. This helped it compete with French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain is stable at about four bars per week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers, such as turning chocolate bars into ice creams, soft drinks, or desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices from the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83 years old, has become an expert in his craft. Although he is interested in trying new things like paper-making and feather-work, he is currently focused on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has honed over the past decade. As he shows me around his apartment, he worries about being boring, but his enthusiasm and the beauty of his creations are captivating.

Cooke points out a pair of shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. He mentions that he wouldn't mind if they don't sell because he has grown fond of them. Initially, he didn't plan to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to hold an exhibition. This led to a successful show in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, featuring 86 pieces with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Some pieces, like the ornaments, are priced around £2,000.

Cooke is open about the high prices, explaining that his work is unique. The gallery owner told him that once he stops creating, his pieces will become even more sought after. Cooke wishes he had started this art form earlier in life, as he feels he could have created even more impressive works. Despite physical limitations now, his creations are far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops.

He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which has led to intricate boxes covered in tiny shells, shaded pictures, and realistic flower baskets. Cooke has developed his own techniques, using materials he finds, like cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases and a special glue from a sail-maker. He washes the shells with washing-up liquid and says his creations seem to come together naturally, though the detail and symmetry suggest otherwise.

Cooke's search for beautiful, especially small, shells has taken him to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming the environment. He argues that many shells are crushed by people or broken by the sea, and he only collects those that are already empty. His work transforms these shells into something greater than their natural state, making his argument quite convincing.

Text: 'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more. 'Kira might be a bit late,' the agency receptionist told me. 'That's okay,' I replied, trying to ignore the negative stereotypes about models being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. Now she was late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided going to the hairdresser was more fun than meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions. But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she came with her mother. Kira wore a simple black dress and trainers, not expensive designer clothes. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a friendly, tall, and pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mom, proud of her successful daughter. Kira seemed a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister suggested she enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should try it,' Kira recalls. 'I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway.' When she got the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away. Kira now finds it challenging to balance her two lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, some people at her school are unkind about her success. 'They say I think too highly of myself.' This must be tough for Kira, as she's not arrogant. She says, 'They think that because I'm a model now, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I'm more confident - not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends understand. They don't say, "Oh, you're always off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, talent, and support for a great career ahead. Not many people can say that before finishing their school exams. As I finish the interview with this successful girl, I ask what she would like to do if she wasn't a model. She pauses and says, 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat in search of valuable metals. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they think they are close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, says they are finding high levels of gold and need to dig a few more meters to reach the concentrated area.

Their gold search began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. After studying 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library, they picked the best area to explore. They spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and clearing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money and need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a bit deeper to reach the gold. Chris Madden says finding a backer is uncertain, but they have some contacts.

As news of their dig spread, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said it would attract more visitors if the Maddens are right, but he hopes it won't lead to many people damaging the hillside.

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in numerous mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, says searching for gold is emotional, adventurous, and exciting, with the hope of finding hidden treasure. He hopes to be lucky this time.

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University as a lecturer and researcher in marine geochemistry, studying chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move, and must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive lasts 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button to release a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant ride.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle on a ship's deck with an instructor, who explained emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill 150 meters into a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees. The only time Rachel felt scared was during a dive with Americans when an explosion occurred. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she might die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the ocean's deepest parts is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind was tired of dealing with foreign timetables, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped back onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I needed was one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere in Europe. Once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds never feel the same. The train's rhythm rocks you into a deep sleep. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to throwing away things like socks that have become too smelly or books once you've finished them. This carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense and reasoning can be ignored, just like the socks and books. All you need is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be special. On our first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the potential of this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to and from our campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting. There was always one more country just over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We weren't completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers, and we only included the most accessible sights in our schedule. This was our chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, all I saw was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and have a good time. In this, we were like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It's as if the city never existed until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what's there, but it's meaningless until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are often boring. While the train trip won't let you discover anything new in a global sense, it's a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to realize this, though for us, it didn't happen right away.

Arriving at an airport in another country only to find out your luggage didn't make it is very frustrating. At best, you'll have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a completely different climate, far from home, and stuck with unsuitable clothing. Airlines don't often share how many bags they lose, but frequent travelers know that losing luggage is a common issue. Even top airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked bags will always be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines require you to check in early to give enough time for your bags to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are set to ensure there's enough time to transfer bags between flights. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. Human errors or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause problems. These issues are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs,' because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport managed over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing luggage is higher at some airports. In the U.S., Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers connect to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or want a cheaper flight, try to stick with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline's baggage office and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who specializes in kingfishers, which are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers and eat fish. The environment where they live is full of soft colors like greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and brightly through this scene, leaving a strong impression even though it is small.

Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He can't quite explain why he is so drawn to them, but they are part of many legends. In Greek mythology, a kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top turned blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, their feather structure reflects light, making them look blue or green depending on the light angle.

Many wildlife photographers are fascinated by kingfishers because of their colors and the fact that, while they avoid humans, they can be watched from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hideout was just an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. The bird came close, but it took him four years to get a good picture. During this time, he spent as much time as possible by streams with kingfishers, even skipping school, which affected his studies.

Despite this, his passion for kingfishers was noticed, and at 16, he became an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant editor and then became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film with just beautiful images and no words. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his deep feelings for the bird, but he knows there's more to his connection with kingfishers than his work can express.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she filled in for an absent assistant during Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She wasn't nervous and felt confident leading an orchestra. Manson, originally from the U.S., works with a London opera company focused on modern music. She is gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has assisted Abbado on several projects since her first opportunity.

**B. Andrew Constantine**
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He feels the timing was perfect, as earlier success might have been overwhelming. The competition opened doors for him, including working with a famous conductor. However, he worries about being labeled as just a "competition winner." He hopes orchestras, like the English Chamber Orchestra, will continue to invite him back, as this is crucial for his career.

**C. Wasfi Kani**
Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties, supporting herself with a job in London's business district until her opera company became professional. Lessons with Sian Edwards were pivotal for her, as she realized size didn't matter in conducting. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, including managing singers' personalities and the inevitable disagreements.

**D. Roger Vignoles**
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a resident musician in an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he anticipated. Vignoles feels his broad musical experience benefits him in conducting. He is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys most.

**E. Wayne Marshall**
Wayne Marshall's conducting career began in 1986 when Simon Rattle noticed him and recommended him to an agent. At 32, he conducted a musical in London on short notice, facing challenges like musicians reading newspapers during performances. He handled it by being firm and clear. Marshall hasn't formally studied conducting, but he is confident and knows what he wants. He believes showing confidence is key, as showing worry can make things worse.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There’s a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park lacks a bit of atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly and helpful. There’s something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus with its amazing trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you’ll get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is great for younger children. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn’t too boring. It’s very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren’t too scary. I’m usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you’re brave. If the kids were older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was worse! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older kids went on several times. Sarah was too small for some, but she enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes varied. Some were great with younger kids, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared to tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over £200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. Christine wanted a job she could do from home, so she started this business, having worked with computers before marriage. It required a lot of money initially, and the start was tough. She managed finances carefully, always informing the bank if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, with local customers often picking up their orders.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum, but after moving to the countryside, she started her own business. She creates 50 different greeting cards, selling them to museums. She works in a large room at home. The downside of working from home is the constant distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her work.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business that has experienced ups and downs. She started eight years ago, and initially, her business grew rapidly, with turnover increasing from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She once managed six full-time staff but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult as jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and employs women who work from their homes. She adapts by lowering prices when needed and exploring new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago to save money and because she loves the rural life. She enjoys flexible working hours, though 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring her to take calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to separate work from home life. Her business focuses on publishing children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated, having worked in London before.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop, with a yearly turnover of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started at home ten years ago, making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients due to her interest in health. As demand grew, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for production, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake decorator. Meg now focuses on the business side rather than baking. Her biggest challenge has been managing finances, as she started with limited funds.

Title: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons talented musicians and composers, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When John and Hetty Watkins, both schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son Paul, they found the cost too high. John decided to learn how to make one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, and John now makes up to twelve violins a year, even selling one to the famous American violinist Jaime Laredo.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano but soon switched to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, chose the piano and composition, finding inspiration in Paul's success rather than feeling overshadowed by it.

Paul's talent with the cello led him to win the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using the cello his father made. Recently, he started playing a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is over 300 years old, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television, but he won't be able to watch it because he has a concert at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw also has a significant event that evening, with his String Quartet premiering in London.

John and Hetty Watkins will need to be both diplomatic and energetic to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules in the coming weeks.

Text: 'Caring for the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you're always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience got him the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents, so I can relate to farmers and understand their problems. Plus, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to pick and press flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. Recently, I wondered where I would find all those flowers, nests, and grasshoppers now. It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault—they were just following government advice.' Gareth says that when he started, farmers and conservationists were often in conflict. Now, they are talking and understanding each other's views. 'We're close to bringing them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting and maintaining trees, and meeting with the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My job is to make sure tasks are completed efficiently and economically. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on paperwork and bills.' Gareth is passionate about his job and, despite being on duty all the time, he enjoys it, especially interacting with the public. Most of them, anyway. 'It's some people's attitude I dislike,' he admits. 'They come in, demand everything, and leave as if it's their right. Being polite to those people can be annoying!' But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. So if you have plenty of that and like the idea of working outdoors, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth—just don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!'

Text: 'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski leads England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people stare?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's it.' 'My life is all about being at my best for the Championships,' Kendra says. 'I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible.' This is her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People expect us to start well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they're exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' England is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play every day, there's no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because there's only one chance.' In the fifteen years she's been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team.' 'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not even notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. These schools offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. Students at these schools spend about one-third to half of their day on music-related activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though they can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, meaning they live at the school full-time, which allows them to grow up with peers who share similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question whether it's wise to admit children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals.'

Separating musically gifted children from an early age can be stressful. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support if needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with music training at a junior department of a music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from major cities like London.

Susan Shepherd is an artist famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny initially doubted some of her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants in the garden, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the process of flowers decaying fascinating. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for perhaps a day and they each form themselves into different shapes. They open out and are fantastic."

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers, thinking they looked artificial. She was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden includes plants from distant countries, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She now has an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isère, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live at the chalet. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says.
