Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.'

Text: 'Changing Lives with a Stranger'

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was difficult because I usually wear a uniform. First, I visited a photo studio, then went to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, while my job is not very stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I find magazines interesting, but I love my job at the zoo, so I will stay there.'

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. 'I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa.'

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air because sometimes I don't see daylight due to my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I was more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job.'

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener from Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it was very satisfying.'

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and it made me feel different—people respected me more. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult.'

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was nervous about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see that some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.'

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers some of the most stunning views of the sea. No matter the weather or season, it's always enchanting. From the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France, making you feel like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I'm especially grateful to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train appeared, hundreds of people rushed to climb in and on top of the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line, lovingly maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing to know is that you should research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the "writing game." No matter what you write, you need to know the markets you're targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are currently accepting. Keep updating this knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always look for new talent, so writers must provide what they want. 

If you're unsure what to write, start by exploring. For example, if you want to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and learn what kind of stories they buy, paying attention to their readers. Editors focus on meeting readers' needs. Writers often ask me, "My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but the work might not be ready for publishing. Most new writers send their work too soon, often before they're ready for the market. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success stories usually involve people with years of experience in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, start on new projects while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more stories. Each one will improve, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any work away—improve it instead. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station, usually airy and clean, felt crowded. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers one by one. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl standing near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, 'Are you traveling to Philadelphia by any chance?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 'Ma'am,' I heard him ask an older woman, 'are you traveling to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't respond, just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't; I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the bench at the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a teacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favor?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my wrist as if checking a watch. (I don't own a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too difficult, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the Philadelphia station, unsure what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. 'I told her to stay put. I said I would find someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a weak excuse, in my opinion. It was more bad luck than one family should have. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have made more sense, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Be careful, lady, I thought to myself.'

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, shares his story about his son Gary, who is now a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's was running a restaurant. When John found the opportunity to start his restaurant, the place was in bad shape, but it was perfect for his plans. This reminded him of his childhood when his mother worked in a factory, and he felt lonely. He wanted to ensure his family had time together, so his wife took care of the children and managed the accounts while he ran the business. They lived above the restaurant and always prioritized family meals, which helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they interacted with customers, giving them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. At seven, he once jumped into a corner bath like it was a pool and knocked himself out. As he grew, he worked for pocket money, starting with small jobs and then helping in the kitchen every weekend by age ten. He was disciplined, often waking up before his father. The family business was for the family, and it was nice to see Gary helping out. Although not very academic, Gary excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adults and sometimes even managed the kitchen, preparing over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would pursue catering because of his talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed a band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advises Gary to focus on one thing, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary, "If you want to achieve something, do it by 30, or it might be too late." At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he quickly finished a morning's work in an hour and helped others. This showed his dedication and skill.

Gary's TV cookery series has become very successful, and John is extremely proud. He always taught Gary that hard work is necessary because nothing is given for free. Gary seized his opportunity and succeeded. John reflects that if children remember even a small part of what parents teach them, it's a success. Seeing Gary's actions and words, John feels Gary must have listened sometimes.

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But for Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had to stay in a hostel and search for a place on her own. Dublin felt like a big unknown to her, and she felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; it was just assumed by everyone at her school that she would leave their small town. Everyone wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle in. But Jo was the only one from her year going to Dublin, and she was doing it alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, which was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were all still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary—a red-brick terraced house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, not in the basement. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf, who was clearly a failed applicant, was coming down. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing.

"Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is to it? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline, wearing a very colorful psychedelic shirt, was a punk, which amazed Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one up close. "I'm Jo, I work in the post office, and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa said they were about to have a mug of tea and brought out three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one with "Other" written on it. "We'll get your name on it if you come to stay," she said kindly.

Text: 'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on their decline. Dolphins are special to us because they are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire dreams of freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and cared for in marine reserves, but this is not true. The lack of protection plans could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two usually live far out at sea and are seen only briefly near ships, so we know little about them. The larger bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The injuries on the few remaining dolphins show they are stressed. Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to pinpoint why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished in one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They also risk getting caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing methods use large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches, showing marks and cuts from these nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can accumulate in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another serious threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air, which may disturb dolphins in unknown ways.

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It's one of the best ways to keep balance in your life, especially when everything around you feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there are many reasons why it's really good for you. Exercise improves your muscle tone and quickly changes your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand or sit with good posture. It prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. Exercise also quickly improves areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons many times, so maybe you're not paying attention anymore. But here's something that might interest you: exercise can help reduce depression and tiredness, and it helps you sleep better. It also helps control stress and can relieve some medical conditions. By now, these reasons should convince you a little. If not, common sense should tell you that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, lifting free weights, or using weight machines. Remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injuries, so start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you. Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body doesn't look good, lacks energy, and is more likely to have minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head up. This will help lift your chest for better breathing and make your abdomen look slimmer. When your chest is balanced while standing, you should be able to see your ankles. Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain good posture, and prevents muscle injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you'll have a more flexible and fit body. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

Text: 'IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? It's the search for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest people to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost nonstop rain, causing many unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive tool so that whenever one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him out. Their teamwork has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their amazing film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's shyest cats was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time following the equally shy jackal. This is common in television partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been going around the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was briefly meeting other people at a safari lodge. 'We do have occasional arguments but we get over them quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he says they get along well because they both see the animals in a similar way. 'When we are moving, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make the tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask.' The rest of their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so food can be a bit of a worry,' says Newman. It can be a tough life, but being alone in such remote areas lets them get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman remembers filming a family of lions where one lioness would often go off on her own. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later they went to film Arctic foxes as a team. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they have to submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We always aim to make a film that is rich in atmosphere, that brings to life the true spirit of the place and animals, and that will touch people's hearts. I believe if you can evoke an emotional response from people, that is better than just appealing to their minds.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her typical day includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her training location and asked if she gets strange looks. She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra's life is now all about being at her best for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to reach peak fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they are expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure and expectations from the home crowd. People expect us to start strong."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." England is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra notes that the World Championships are challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games. Unlike a series, you only have one chance in the Championships, so you must be ready."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But after the final whistle, we become different people. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. As captain, she believes in having a strong mental attitude and leading by example. She sees her role as supporting and encouraging her team.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye, with her loyal supporters cheering her on.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry, studying chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers into the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They can't stand or move much and must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience. The first time she entered the vehicle, she was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space.

Rachel has now made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees.

The only time Rachel felt scared was during a dive with Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the ocean's deepest parts is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is on the ocean floor, seeing things no one else has seen. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body language, how fast or slow we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to present yourself in the best possible way." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more if I had managed to control my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to learn about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and convince others of your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests you have a few questions ready and avoid speaking in long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City went from being exciting to a grind—no one was having fun anymore. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counselor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to get back to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left all our friends, but we've been lucky—our friendships have survived, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and seasons, so you need a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but never found the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

Text: 'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always loved sports. I tried many different ones, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it's worth it because without dedication, I wouldn't have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a TV show about surfing. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who aren't in sailing. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I wouldn't want to be a big celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.'

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this hotel. This transformation allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests. 

General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, like guest preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. MacCann believes the system will pay for itself over time. He is very positive about its efficiency and features. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can record any number of preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C.

For guests, especially business travelers, the in-room technology is very appealing. MacCann estimates that up to 65% of the hotel's business will come from this market. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future upgrades. Extra cables have been installed to handle new advancements. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be easily replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann ensures that guests do not feel overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, comfortable, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel benefits by offering a popular and successful dining option without financial risks.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get energy from excitement and challenges. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. Activities with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, are also energizing. Dance is expressive and uplifting. Feeling bored or that life is pointless can drain your energy. Being effective, even in small ways, boosts your energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a chore. Enjoying your work keeps you from feeling down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel great. When I only get six hours, I feel sluggish. Exercise gives me energy, but finding the energy to start is hard! I do yoga once a week and try workout tapes at home. Exercise lifts my spirits. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't rely on healthy eating for energy; it's my natural enthusiasm and positivity. I dislike negative attitudes. I believe in enjoying life and seizing the moment. Enjoyment is key. Achieving goals is important. My job is exciting, surrounded by lively young people. I love being busy and sociable. I enjoy taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun, which helps me relax during travel."

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. Working with kids is great because they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural reaction from interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking or drinking, but I don't have an exercise routine. My exercise is playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love turning wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area by breaking it up and adding soil. It was more satisfying than workouts or tennis. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy. I find it hard to write without an audience. I also enjoy exploring private lands like a child, even if I get caught."

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"You need to respect and be interested in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you dislike drains your energy. I used to be on committees and disliked the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus it on what matters most to you."

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is key in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually make longer movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn basic figures, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To achieve this, you should regularly do exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises for the legs, back, and shoulders are important, especially for the ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness. Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great fitness program.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson spoke with three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "The work is really tough right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to focus on each day. When I'm extremely tired, my coach might give me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you'll get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. Performing at Annika's level requires a lot of time and energy, and you have to want it yourself. People often say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people worldwide and gained confidence from her success."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I'd do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they're happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started when she was 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box's living area. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting arrogant; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it immediately. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. I also don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this talent, she should reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'What do you want to be, the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about a centimeter. More and more very tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're creating a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We're now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diets, which is having a big impact. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by the few remaining hunter-gatherer tribes. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas on the planet were taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. Despite this, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gatherer land. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the variety of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with its own challenges. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't adapted. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers constantly have to update their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We can't keep growing forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller as an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies retain heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, the growth of human beings could be countered by global warming.'

Text: 'Studio Audiences What's it like to be in the audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical issues, studio audiences are a common part of TV life, yet they remain a mystery to many of us. Watching them get excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least prestigious. I've heard that even TV professionals look down on them - one cameraman even compared them to cattle. I used to think studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. But there's no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, professions, and income levels. TV shows try to attract different types of people for different programs. Those of us who prefer watching TV at home can't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why apply for tickets, travel far, and endure hours of boredom in an uncomfortable studio just to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to appear on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I spoke to Angela: 'Why did she come?' It was a chance to be on TV.' Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it's like. You sit there, squeezed among strangers, while someone holds up signs saying APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh as instructed. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager says, 'We always hope a show will be good enough not to need these signs.' But is there any real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him on TV at home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from my seat, all I saw was the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were filmed so far away that I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor. Going to a studio might be a bad way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where nature and human elements mix. When I travel, I like visiting charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. At eight, I went to school in England and would cycle to the village of Lastingham on Saturdays. Cycling was my escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and different to me, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a diary, which was my first step into travel writing, a field where I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by enthusiasts. I always travel first class because it's only a little more expensive. The scenery isn't spectacular; the train goes through Romney Marsh with sheep and a canal. But I love when the train passes through back gardens. For a moment, we can see people in their daily lives, like making tea or doing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a tiny train, looking into others' homes. The ordinary landscape attracts me—just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful, remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and rocky, so there aren't many people. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There aren't many people living or visiting there. It's a hidden, empty, and remote area, and I love the feeling of space. I found it by chance as a student and have visited every year since, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It saddens me that he's growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon, England, at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream place—a magical, secluded, romantic house where you only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day of Animal Chaos

We're a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she found a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank for temporary animal guests, and we liked to admire them and learn about them from our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help from their bedroom. I rushed in to find our cat, Domino, with a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch, while the kids were waving their arms to stop him. I joined the chaos and accidentally tripped, landing on the floor.

As I lay there, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. The room was a mess of screaming kids, a barking dog, and the snake striking at everything. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I turned my attention to the snake. It didn't have any obvious weak points, so I sat on the floor like a snake charmer, trying to calm it down. Eventually, the snake relaxed, and I carefully picked it up. I took it to the end of the garden, hoping it would choose to live in the garden shed. But when I let go of its head, it wrapped around my shoulders like a shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter.

We stood there, my four children, the snake, and I, in the evening light. My eldest, DJ, explained why the snake stayed with me: "You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed it up for all of us: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a letter! In our fast-paced world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, for me, receiving a letter is special in a way that no other form of communication can match. There's the excitement when it arrives, the pleasure of seeing who it's from, and finally, the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I would write to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or messy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Sometimes my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday events involving my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it's the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I often dated people who had to work or study far away, so we stayed in touch by writing letters. Instead of hurting the relationships, letter writing seemed to make them better. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! And it's even more exciting when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we regularly write to each other. I can improve my French (she doesn't speak English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was worth reporting on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, arranged by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

Title: 'Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art'

In the French Alps, at Mont Bego, there are tens of thousands of ancient rock carvings that are being damaged. These 36,000 drawings, which are about 4,000 years old, include images of cows, fields, and gods. The site was once a place for prayer and worship. However, as more tourists visit, the carvings are being harmed by graffiti and careless actions.

Jean Clottes, who leads the International Committee on Rock Art, warns that if the damage continues, the drawings might not last another 50 years. He has seen tourists walking on the carvings, which wears them down, and some even take pieces home as souvenirs. When visitors can't take clear photos, they rub the drawings to make them more visible, which further damages them. Some people even scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.

Experts disagree on how to protect the site. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, suggests closing the mountain to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this is the only way to save the site and allow research to continue. However, Clottes thinks this approach is too extreme and would upset local residents. He emphasizes the importance of preserving the site, which is classified as a historic monument.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also opposes closing the site. He suggests allowing people to visit but acknowledges the challenge of preventing damage due to the site's large size. He mentions the lack of funds to hire enough guards and considers charging an entry fee as a possible solution, since government funding is unlikely.

Annie Echassoux, a researcher in Nice, is concerned that easier access to the mountain, such as by hiring vehicles, will lead to more damage. She believes the area should be roped off and guided tours provided. She insists that financial constraints should not stop efforts to protect the site, as it is a historic area. If no action is taken, future generations may lose these valuable drawings.

Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her kids want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty when she gives in to their demands. She also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed before even leaving the house. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Kids often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the appealing ads they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their kids eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if kids only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell kids to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major source of stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her kids and has taught her son to be critical of ads. They now have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his kids because they're unhealthy, even while buying treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent and says his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for kids. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

Text: 'Climbing Walls: A New Era Once, climbers only went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd watches closely. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by just two fingers, is French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new and fast-developing technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. With cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This kept their fingers strong and helped them avoid boredom. Soon, many sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges to grip. Many of these early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had design issues. Walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and angled slabs. Another problem was that once built, the walls couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds. In 1985, a Frenchman, Francois Savigny, created a material that he shaped into forms like those on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as free-standing structures. A system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers endless new holds.'

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. And yes, acting is a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it's a personal choice, and only you can take responsibility for your dream. There are no easy paths - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after training, you will succeed. It's about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and acting can be exciting and glamorous, with the chance of big rewards. People often ask what talent is. I think it's natural skill plus imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you're doing. Why do people want to act? It's hard to explain. In theatre, it's about the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what drives actors. If you ask successful actors how they made it, they might just shrug. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they don't take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is an actor's biggest enemy. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Then suddenly, you get an audition, but you might not get the part, no matter how much you want it. So, actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and possible rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. And remember, rejection is possible from the moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. It's up to you, because if you don't care enough, no one else will.'

**Food for Everyone: Our Top Cookbook Picks**

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and are known for being exciting yet practical for the average cook. Her book, "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple, expert guidance on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it's the go-to book for anyone wondering which single cookbook to own.

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, "Blanc Mange," accompanies his first TV series and aims to make us better cooks by explaining how ingredients work together. With over 80 recipes, this practical book also explains why some dishes fail and introduces basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's very skilled at it.

C. "Le Cordon Bleu" is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the school released "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," featuring 100 of its most respected recipes. While these recipes are classics, they are still fresh and have been updated to be healthier. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

D. Fast food often gets a bad reputation, but Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that you can make delicious food quickly. Nigel believes you can create something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This book includes over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in just 30 minutes. Written in his enjoyable style, these recipes prove that fast food can also be great food. If you're skeptical, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall at that age. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about a centimeter. More and more very tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're evolving into a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We're now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diets, which is having a big impact. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by a few remaining tribes of hunter-gatherers. One study found that they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas on the planet were taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing of the New World, was actually a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. Despite this, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the variety of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with its own issues. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't adapted. Standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly updating their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We can't keep growing forever. There must be a natural limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller as an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies retain heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even with proper nutrition. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even more. In other words, human growth could be countered by global warming.'

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City went from being an exciting place to work to a boring routine—no one was having fun anymore. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to get back to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. It was a leap into the unknown. We moved to the north of England, where we didn't know anyone. It meant leaving our friends, but we've been lucky—many of them visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
After working for five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and seasons, so there's always too much to do, and you need a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care when working for a company, but when your name is on everything, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but never found the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets.
