I never felt in control before, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

Two brothers are turning their childhood game into a successful business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, both in their forties, are sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, playing pichenotte, a game they learned from their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte. Lucien, originally from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA. The family played it often, especially on weekends and holidays, and continued to do so after moving to New Mexico. The game was unknown in the southern USA, so visitors were often intrigued by it.

Three years ago, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was worn out and decided to make a new one. The new board was impressive, and soon relatives and friends wanted their own. Curious about the game's appeal, the brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were hesitant to play, but once they tried it, they couldn't stop. This sparked interest in the game's origins, and Dave discovered it likely started in India as 'carroms', evolved into 'squails' in Britain, and was brought to Canada by British immigrants. The French-Canadian version is called pichenotte.

Pichenotte is a skill-based game for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks', which they flick across a board using their fingers. Points are scored by flicking pucks into a hole or onto concentric rings around it. The game is quick, usually lasting two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the bar, the Lagasse brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships were organized, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As demand grew, the brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards so far. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. They sell for $595 on the brothers' website.

There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their business will continue to grow. They dream of one day replacing their workshop with a luxury car, but for now, they enjoy playing the game that might make them rich.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a piece of unused land, flat and covered with brambles. For years, it was seen as worthless. However, with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the constant support of his wife, transformed this land into the beautiful place you see today. During the construction, many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to create the landscape. Bulldozers and digging machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.

Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the Model Village. These plants had to be chosen carefully because they needed to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to withstand all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. You will notice that the models are all made to the same scale, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques.

The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses. The model buildings show traditional British architectural styles but are not based on any specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch the models, as any damage can take hours to repair. Photography is allowed from the paths only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to see the models in action.

At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your feedback. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet the high standards of the rest of the village, as we are constantly updating and replacing them. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, these photos cause great harm to public figures when their private moments appear on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos, and since she was in a hotel, where privacy is expected, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't take action. It's scandalous that the PCC didn't investigate on its own. It should also look into the recent outrageous story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star hasn't made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on these and other shameful attacks? Initially, this seems like a good idea. It would likely result in many decisions against newspapers, reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public wouldn't support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it wouldn't be financially viable to wait for unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several challenges. How would it decide to start an inquiry? Should it encourage the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Celebrities and royalty might expect any story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. Above all, the role is too large. How could the PCC realistically monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there's the embarrassment factor. No matter how seriously someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the further embarrassment of an investigation? Most people likely want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they fear it could become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian also suffered from the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor recently, when his family was again photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would re-run the pictures with a new story about his 'anger', claiming it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to college graduates starting their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job after just a few weeks. Instead, we are discussing those who are taking a significant step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience, skills, and a clearer idea of their career path. 

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Ask yourself if you want to specialize in a specific area, move up to higher responsibilities, or switch to a broader field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should challenge you, help you grow, and give you more responsibility.

If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were supportive, and she learned office skills and improved her word processing. However, there was no room for growth. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, she has become more capable, and her job has expanded. Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Although her job title is the same, her duties have changed. She has moved from mainly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also deals with various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but most of them have learned this skill because they needed to. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny: When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B. Michaela: Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive, thinking that's how confident people acted. But I learned that confidence is about believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lose confidence, so I talk to myself to overcome those fears.

C. Lisa: People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is crucial. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when talking to someone friendly. My mom once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves.' That's good advice. You gain confidence by facing your fears. I was nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I wouldn't be that scared again.

D. Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over the years. By doing my job and learning from mistakes, I become more confident. I'm popular at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me, and that's okay. You have to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's better to see real progress than aim too high and achieve nothing.

E. Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my opinions. When I started in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' Writing down a few notes helped me feel more secure. Everyone gets nervous about public speaking. The key to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. Each kite was exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest and most serious kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held up the kites, and a line of nervous competitors held their kite strings, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites shot up into the sky like rockets. Over 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them requires real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I received five such invitations that day and decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large polished room. As night approached, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but my plans didn't allow it. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into granite mountains covered with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A narrow boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and thousands of creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was an amazing view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the path. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were only being friendly. Kelantan might be famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its people's kindness.'

Text: 'What kind of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all need to shop. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I'm a shopping addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it keeps me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is just like me, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real amount - I always say it cost less! The real price always sounds too high. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know exactly what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something else I'd rather do. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices! E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are gifts. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly! F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much! H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want and never buy things immediately. I check other shops to find a better deal - it takes me a long time! I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I drag myself out, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!'

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE Like any other university, the Open University offers degrees. However, you can continue working while you study. It can also introduce you to a wide range of interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet many different people. Your qualification might also lead to new career opportunities. You don't attend lectures at the Open University; instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Of course, there are exams to take, just like at any university. If you want more information, simply fill out the form below. It could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch 18th-century artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist painted flowers as they bloomed in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also features Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures related to the special exhibition happens every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will focus on Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce improvements in the Gallery restaurant. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Fees should be paid at the main office. The centre is open to everyone and aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for the public. Groups should inform the centre before visiting.

Windsurfing - One-day Course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment).

One-day Adventure Course
This is a great opportunity to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course introduces outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You don't need to be very fit or have previous experience. Just be interested. Course fee: £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country, with sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group Day and Residential Courses
We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that children only do activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health for this program.

Text: 'STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN KEEP GROWING Millions of people of all ages enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collection and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world. Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors get new British stamps. As a Club member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these in three ways: we can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you, send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or send you individual stamps to arrange in your own special book. The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too, with a two-year membership costing just £5. You can even get a discount if a group of you join at the same time. We think you'll agree that this is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get our helpful 4-page guide to collecting, with more tips on how to add to your collection and useful addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps. Every two months, you'll receive a copy of the club magazine, full of competitions and quizzes, and the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones that are out there waiting to be found. So join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join the Club, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days of receiving your application.'

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, a farmer like Mr. Green would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Enter our story competition! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for talented writers who can create great stories. The judges, including novelist Mary Littlejohn, TV reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor Susan Hitchins, want to see interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who entered followed this advice. Common topics were love, family, and friendship problems. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so that people want to read them. Write about everyday things in a new and surprising way to keep the reader interested. Get your facts right If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure you are accurate. Don't write about things unless you are sure about them. Hold the reader's attention Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A bad ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of an unusual ending. Think about the characters Make the people in your story come alive for the reader by using the right words to make them seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 entry fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we don't have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to assist her work. During that period, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone involved with it was at risk. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station houses a unique collection of historic trains from across Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only on days when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, the James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. Special low fares are available for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular venue for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grass, and they can be found everywhere on Earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can survive in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass can quickly recover after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area because, after they eat the grass, it starts to grow back quickly, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, who has always loved fashion, recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating patterns. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear label. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal's business has grown significantly, and she feels very fortunate. "What I do is my hobby—and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this," she says.

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has been known for its excellent service, welcoming guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town center, about 20 minutes away by bus. Buses to various parts of the town stop outside the hotel, but avoid buses with the blue "Express" sign as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of each corridor. The hotel offers a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. Parking is available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed, and guests should respect others' comfort. Keep noise from tapes or CDs low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If arriving by train, it is recommended to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a child, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and took drama classes at the same time. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with fans all over the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she ended up on a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry. He gave her some milk and started asking around. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. Since it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is mostly known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, although the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to board. Our first stop, where the Ghan waited four hours, was at Katherine. Some passengers got off here for a boat trip up the gorge. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and stayed to watch the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs isn't very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered on everything the advertisements promised, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.'

Each year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard that it feels like ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, like lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothing. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon got steep, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we weren't so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as challenging as climbing up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we've just moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place made entirely of wood, just like our old school. However, this new building is one of the first in our country to be really environmentally friendly. It took months to build, and we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, although it meant losing some lovely open space. The noise from the machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think it would never be finished.

Now, we have five very large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old, very old school next door. We share one room with the town for meetings and other events. There's also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms that we can't wait to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you'll notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from us—the students, teachers, and computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in. When we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the school roof. The builders put it there because it's a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. Our electricity comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins really fast. It's so big that you can see it from miles away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we're already using the new building, some parts are still being added. For example, we're putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We're very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any discounted books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you save money compared to the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully selected from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month to keep you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a fiction or reference title they think is especially worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this don't come every day. To become a member, just fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and actually enjoying it. As I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron was there with his two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost: I'm 72 years old, far from home, and very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. After I explained, he kindly gave me money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver my story, he let me keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, with everything still inside. I want to express how grateful I am to everyone who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Sharks are some of the most feared animals in the ocean. They are excellent hunters because they have good eyesight and can sense movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes them very dangerous to smaller sea animals, which they eat. While sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For instance, most sharks need to keep swimming to breathe and stay alive, so they rarely sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can stop moving entirely. This is helpful for researchers who need to study sharks, as it allows them to learn more about these interesting creatures.

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, and returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, you'll take Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. A coach will take you from Sydney to Melbourne, passing through Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia are included. You will stay for nineteen nights in quality hotels with full continental breakfast. The package includes a day trip to Ayers Rock, a full-day boat trip on the Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes are covered, as well as hotel baggage handling. An experienced Globewise Tour Manager will be with you throughout the trip. PERTH Enjoy long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants, lush green parks, and the beautiful Swan River. A city sightseeing tour is included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs, located in the heart of Aboriginal country. A full sightseeing tour is included. Visit the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Travel to Yulara National Park. Visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock, known for its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Then fly to the lively seaside town of Cairns to relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF A full day's boat trip on the famous reef is included, with the chance to see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Experience the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city. A sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House are included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city sightseeing tour is included, or you can choose to visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip, you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around and asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak some Russian, and then they started speaking English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is really nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are really hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. That makes me confident I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

Text: 'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the midnight sun. However, in winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be interesting to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide. When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm winter clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests are also advised to bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks, and to wear shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items and the equipment you need when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store for special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (available only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (available only between 3 am and 8 am). Normally, the store will be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for 24 hours straight on its first day. However, it had to close just half an hour after opening. A police officer at the scene said: 'We were told a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly for space inside. Another issue was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. I was surprised that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store, which completely blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: 'I waited in line for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained the situation. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations.

**Society Magazines**  
We publish several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Society members can enter for free, while non-members pay a £5 entry fee. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and building their confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the Society's social hub. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in the heart of London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Text: 'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where competitors dive to great depths on a single breath. In 2003, Tanya Streeter made history by diving 120 meters into the ocean and returning to the surface without assistance. She had gone deeper the previous year but used a balloon to help her ascend. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the first woman in any sport to break a man's world record. A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. Despite reports of serious accidents involving other divers, some people argue that free-diving is too dangerous. However, Tanya disagrees, emphasizing that safety and training are the most important aspects. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine remains consistent. She spends two-thirds of her time on land-based training at the gym, with the rest split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, preferring fast walking to build fitness. When she starts practice dives, she usually travels away from home, aiming for fourteen dives over four weeks, with rest days in between to avoid fatigue. When not preparing for an event, Tanya often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research projects or films. Growing up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, she spent her childhood swimming and exploring rock pools to observe sea life. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She believes her fame in some countries helps people listen to her on environmental issues. Looking ahead, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. Since she started free-diving at twenty-five, she emphasizes that she doesn't plan to retire from the sport anytime soon.'

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people in the cinema industry thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors came up with original new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never thought I'd spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before starting university. While in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. She was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on essays. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I'm not from an acting family, though my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I had a busy social life too. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do. I've since acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends.''

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a global company that is growing quickly around the world. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of what I have learned is in this book. I believe that our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our values. This book is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares these ideas with the world and makes them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that an exciting thought, and I hope you do, too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER

JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and toilet. The ship is air-conditioned and features a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary:

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. Upon arrival, your guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

Day 2: Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship to travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey takes four hours.

Day 3: Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine production. You can enjoy local food and drinks at dinner.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the Douro River Valley to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river back to Oporto, where you will spend the night on the Lady Ivy May.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.'

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It contains water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than 300 types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. It was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food; it can also be used for sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich has been a religious center for a long time, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is smaller compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, especially in insurance services, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall.' For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the main car park. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved to create a city center park on the Mall's roof, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has managed to combine the best of the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a desert city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, about a dozen hot-air balloons launched from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current site outside the city.

What to See

The balloon pilots stay in radio contact and light up their burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist spots. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It's surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality for just £6.99 quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less famous writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be cautious with Jane Harris's Those Nails—it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there's a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at ages three and four, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, happening once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes. It is important for parents to be actively involved in the lessons. From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and their music reading skills. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine, the band, released their third CD last week called 'Here Again', which follows their previous album 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance track, it's clear that the band is moving away from focusing only on slow songs. The second track is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they are excellent and could easily become hit singles. Singer Rob Letchford performs exceptionally well, hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which have caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets shouldn't worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the upbeat ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks weren't as strong. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it wasn't the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and interesting look at everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events of the time, such as disease outbreaks, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his flaws - he often fell asleep in church or admired pretty girls. He describes his home life, like arguments with his wife and how they made up, and his worries about her illness. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work with the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not made to be comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to produce many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to pause my running career. I wanted to help more women discover the sport, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to boost their confidence to start running. So, I decided to create a women's running club in my area because I was frustrated with many race organizers. They often complain about the lack of women in the sport but use it as an excuse not to provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women joined, ranging from young to old, fit to unfit. They were mainly interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like along a river. Initially, they could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and general fitness. I wanted to contribute to women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress almost as much as they have.'

The History of the Iditarod - The Last Great Race on Earth

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, supplies could be delivered by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach these towns. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main transport method.

However, in 1925, the dogs were needed again when a disease called diphtheria broke out in Nome. The medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, the only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the snow, and Togo proved to be a reliable leader. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to move forward, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.
