Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so it's not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are kept at around -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer. Building it requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one minded that I was a girl, but then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed she was very fast. "He talked to me about athletics, but I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and started training me. It was really hard, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could succeed in athletics and help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her for training. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had refused before because she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot." Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year living happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the canyon's beautiful rocks. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You need to wear special shoe covers to protect the glass from scratches. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the sky.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as impressive. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is unique because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains, allowing residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver daily on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey is still an exciting adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you pass through some of the most beautiful scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals in zoos were often trained to perform for visitors. This is no longer the case, as zoos now focus on letting people see animals in their natural behavior. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters of zoos argue that they allow us to learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which wouldn't be possible otherwise. On the other hand, critics believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also point out that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat inappropriate food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half do. But anyone who is eager to play comes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music, but you also feel part of its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a network of underground channels, dug in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. These dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs with a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and go back home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And what about the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. You can read or listen to the stories accepted by these media on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers across the country where young people can meet and join projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. 

Sophie, a former member, says: 'I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article on young people's views on hip hop music. I was impressed by the young journalists and the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories on their own. I joined the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and stayed a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I imagined. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online.'

Get involved at every level

When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff during these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

**About the Flights**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. We use a full-size passenger plane, a Boeing 747. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have lived on Antarctic research stations give talks about the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you a pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. Over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to share the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see the sights from both sides of the plane.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite cloud images and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife is at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. To see wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can take photos. All cameras are welcome. We also offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking skills. These weekly lessons, held in small classes, are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times on snow, and even more on ice. 

Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law but ended up going to art school. He found traditional drawing classes hard but continued painting. In his late twenties, he received a grant from the Italian government to study art. This experience made him interested in early Italian artists, which influenced some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he says he never knows exactly how it will turn out. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound simple, saying, 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make sketches before starting a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their portraits while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he doesn't follow any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn't like the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our house with their guitars and other electric equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. I must admit that, even though their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical skill—after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music I did when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain—Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives students important life experiences outside the classroom, along with preparing them for exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the morning and spend the afternoon doing useful activities like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body, with students from various social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students receive grants to help pay. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them attend thanks to government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education with methods that truly work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent salary, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me mentally. I felt stuck and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy, carefree, and hopeful. I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. Still, I am grateful for the chance to study because I know a qualification is important for getting a fulfilling job, which matters a lot to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out partying. There are also typical student perks like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in life has been a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic and built his first car in 1893. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he created the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next one start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course begins in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. It lasts for 6 weeks and costs £150. If you would rather start in June, we offer another course that lasts 10 weeks for £200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. 'You have to carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and eventually, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I'm usually a clean person, but there's no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only bring enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the climb, and people often invite her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science TV program. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!'

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't make it to my party yesterday. Jon mentioned you had a bad cold and chose to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was great; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends came, and they gave me some wonderful presents. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday.

Love, Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places because the winters in Canada are too cold for them to survive. Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do when autumn comes.' Bill had a small plane, so he decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn's cold weather arrived, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to come back. They didn't show up, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't locate them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way home without his help!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold each jar for £1 to her friends and quickly doubled the £500. Initially, her parents were not happy with her making jam and wanted her to study, hoping she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther continued with her jam-making. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She also started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She made various foods and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She became so busy that she needed to hire people to help her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to go to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The movie starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm really sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline'

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they keep cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to prevent them from getting too warm. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people weren't interested in buying sweaters. So, she started making socks instead. People loved the socks because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began. Initially, she made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are made by machines there.

Jenny's socks come in six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different styles for walkers, sports enthusiasts, and skiers. She is busiest during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. Jenny's office walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived here three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school in Brighton. The students are from many different countries, and I have made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He mentioned that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave and forget to close a door or window. He also noted that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually home then. However, he explained that winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Additionally, many houses are empty during this time as people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's houses when people are away and to contact the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to make your house secure,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of assistance is free.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I just wanted to say thank you for letting me stay at your lovely home for two nights. It was great to see you both again. I've attached the photos of your children that you wanted. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you like them. I'm really enjoying my new camera.

Next week, I'm going to visit my sister in New York. I plan to take many photos there as well. It's been a long time since I last saw her.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming, people gathered plants and fruit from forests to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to grow their own food. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, and their villages gradually expanded. Some villagers could focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was challenging when the weather was bad, and some people didn't have enough to eat. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it is transported thousands of kilometers to reach our homes.'

Nicola Peet started working after finishing school at eighteen. She first went to college and then got a job at a local airport. After nine months, she joined Saudi Arabian Airlines and later became an air hostess with British Airways. Four years later, she became a manager. Here’s what she says about her job: "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach air hostesses and help them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. The first thing I do at work is check flight times on my computer and then talk to some of the air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. After a long trip, all I want to do is eat and sleep! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back in my home country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love,  
Sophie

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

Text: People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various jobs. For instance, the weather greatly affects farmers. In the past, farmers would spend a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even access weather information on their mobile phones. Despite modern technology, many people still believe in traditional weather sayings. For example, they say that if the sky is red in the evening, the next day will be sunny. Some also believe that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they usually enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have been spending their weekends in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because they have a lot of homework. Instead, they have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who has difficulty with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words by seeing pictures and hearing information rather than just reading. Frazer wanted to help him. So, Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to develop a computer game, and now it's ready to use. The game involves speaking and pictures. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Getting enough sleep is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard for me to sleep because my mind is full of music. Exercise is also important. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports centre. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's healthy. I aim for about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. It's important not to work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's beneficial to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since my doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat a lot of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy burgers occasionally!'

Bollywood, the film industry in Mumbai, India, produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, even bigger than the USA's. Watching films is the favorite pastime for most Indians, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India, earning Bollywood over $500 million last year from international sales. Indian actors make more films annually than Hollywood actors, but they earn less money. As a result, most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to produce, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard but only for a few years. However, Amitabh Bachchan, considered by some as India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning almost 40 years.

I am Bill Bryson. I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. However, for the past three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so we will stay for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss my new book. Most writers don't enjoy traveling around to promote their books, but I don't mind. I like visiting new places and meeting people. It's very different from my life in the U.S. when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular trimming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and the police also use them because they are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and great with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This summer, she had a very interesting holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two large towns. 'It was very challenging because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite class today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is the first book by David Reilly. David started writing after teaching English for several years. The story is about Maha, a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

Hard Work  
This is the twentieth book by Joanna Jones. Hard Work tells the story of Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they don't have much money. One day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in their shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. The story is about Tina, a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. However, one day she meets a man who invites her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina decide to do?

Horse racing has been an important sport throughout history. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses were brought to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, in the early 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing at once. Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball, and it is also popular in many other countries.

Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job. He travels around the world making TV shows. "People welcome me everywhere, and when I return home, I remember all the amazing experiences from each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but he still wants to travel to South America and return to Australia someday. On his trips, Nick is accompanied by a team that brings cameras and other filming equipment. He doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with his travels for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick comes back, she enjoys hearing his travel stories. However, there can be challenges. Once, while Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he learned that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so relieved when I heard she was better," he recalls.

Parrots are beautiful birds with bright colors and long tails. You might have seen them in forests or zoos. They live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. Parrots usually stay in large groups and love eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very loud but also smart, making it easy to teach them to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch them perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a charming village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.'

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England, where he cuts the grass and waters the flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. This is because John, who is 35 years old, is currently the top singer in Japan. He visited Japan a few months ago to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station to request his songs again. In Japan, John uses the stage name Jon Otis, but he plans to continue working in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I need to keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have bills to pay!" The other gardeners are unaware of his fame in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This won't change our lives. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Memo To: All Staff  
Subject: Holidays  
From: D Brown  
Date: 22.2.02  

I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, provide me with two date options. Please send me your response by the end of the month. Thank you.  
D Brown  

---

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green  
Date: 23.2.02  

Could I take two weeks' holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that's not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December?  
John

Line Dancing

Thousands of people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. You can find clubs and classes for this activity in almost every town. According to Fiona Lever, a teacher, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups, making it a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. Boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open areas of Africa, while the others live in Asian forests. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat only grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos at birth and stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police at all. A few old men used to guard the city streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London began to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed home as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group of people to catch thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very large and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are quite well paid, and for the few officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and you can rent bicycles. The trip costs £25. It gets very cold at night, so bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films, plays, and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be hard, so consider booking your hotel now!

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here every year for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy," he says. "First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then, you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a great week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us. Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can. Greg '

Madame Tussaud's

One very popular tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie helped her uncle with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While there, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her wax figures are still on display today.

Text: 'BICYCLES Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. As bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure activities. Nowadays, cars are used more often than bicycles because they are faster and protect you from the rain. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers and it's hard to find parking spaces.'

Last summer, I went to Thailand with my family for a beach holiday. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of big white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started painting on its card. The keepers helped by giving them new brushes with paint and taking away the old ones. Slowly, the elephants followed their keepers' instructions and drew pictures. I was amazed! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest of the big cats, reaching up to 3.7 meters in length from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often cool off in pools when it's hot. Lions are unique among big cats because they live in large family groups called prides. In these groups, several lions work together to hunt and provide food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they have a clear view to track other animals. All big cats need excellent eyesight to hunt smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I need to return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please let me know when you are available and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then. Best wishes, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There's a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please try to be on time! Best wishes, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm excited to tell you that I got a new job last month in the city center. I'm working at a Tourist Information Office, and it's very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction when running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the size of chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson from Britain began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now, at 23, she has won many competitions in this sport. We interviewed her during a snowboarding competition in Switzerland last week and asked why she started snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed all kinds of sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become quite good in just a few months." 

We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it's so beautiful. However, free-riding, which is snowboarding without competing, is the best thing in the world for me."

We also asked what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet, because at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please give me a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel. Is there a car park available? I expect to arrive around 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. Thank you for your assistance. Yours faithfully, Mark Jones'

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. People of all ages have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different routes to reach the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers manage to reach the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through the water at speeds over 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. Otters can close their ears and nose, allowing them to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain because the rivers were very polluted. The dirty water killed many fish and insects, leaving otters with little to eat. Today, the rivers are clean again, and there is plenty of food for otters.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I'm fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family, and I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Tom

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I really enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine. I will be with him for two weeks before returning home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. The weather was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write to you again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I'm planning to visit your country next month with two friends. We haven't decided where to stay yet. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the city center. Can you assist us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the city center can be pricey, but I have some good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about your visit, and she said you can all stay at her house. She has more bedrooms than I do! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people work together to create a building. The architect designs the building's appearance and draws plans to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I've grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have much money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is known as the Cerne Giant because it is near the village of Cerne. No one is sure when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 meters and possibly the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she was always cheerful and smiling, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of the year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail, but it's tough for him when she overtakes him and he can't keep up. Gail trains hard, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually about cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Text: 'Piano players - when they were young

Ivan Petrov

Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. Ivan's mother started teaching him piano when he was six. By ten, he wanted to write music and soon composed his first song.

Oleg Gagarin

Oleg was the youngest of five children. At four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. When Oleg was six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. He quickly started winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

Josef Heptmann

Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but he hopes to write his own music one day.'

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, 13 years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office and in the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me if she doesn't like something," Bill says. His ten grandchildren, who don't live nearby, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading. 

Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, "The Sheepdog," which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always liked animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." Last year, "The Sheepdog" was made into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film," he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, featuring a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed pictures of current news events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these because newspapers didn't have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. We don't know exactly why they became extinct. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied in appearance. There were over 5000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex wasn't as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. The black and white panda bear, which everyone loves, comes from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in tropical areas around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water but can move quickly both in water and on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat anything they can catch, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and all of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. They can live for a long time; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

**A History of Air Travel**

In 1783, two French brothers created the first hot air balloon that could carry people. Then, 120 years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first airplane with an engine and flew it. By 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. In the 1950s, they became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, the Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, capable of flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York just four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it's hard to imagine a world without them.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The Globe Theatre was a round building without a roof, so people got cold and wet if it rained. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same area near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but last week we visited the Great Barrier Reef. The water was so warm, and I loved swimming there. The fish were all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
